data.title: Black Heritage Trail®
data.description: The Black Heritage Trail® showcases residences and community buildings associated with a Black community that thrived on, and near, the north slope of Beacon Hill before, during, and after the American Civil War. Throughout that time, this community struggled and organized for equal rights and access to equal education. Community members championed the movement to abolish slavery and even housed freedom seekers on their journey along the Underground Railroad.

park.fullName: Boston African American National Historic Site
park.name: Boston African American

tags: Boston African American National Historic Site

stops.significance: The Robert Gould Shaw and Massachusetts 54th Regiment Memorial commemorates one of the first African American regiments of the Civil War. Following his Emancipation Proclamation in 1863, President Lincoln called for the raising of Black regiments. Massachusetts Governor John Andrew soon created the Massachusetts 54th Volunteer Infantry and chose Robert Gould Shaw, the son of prominent abolitionists, to serve as its colonel. Through their heroic, yet tragic, assault on Fort Wagner, South Carolina on July 18, 1863, in which Shaw and many of his men died, the 54th helped erode Northern public opposition to the use of Black soldiers and inspired the enlistment of more than 180,000 Black men into the U.S. forces. To commemorate this brave Black regiment, Bostonians chose Augustus St. Gaudens to create this high relief bronze monument, which sits prominently on Beacon St. across from the Massachusetts State House. Unveiled in 1897, this monument depicts the 54th as they marched down Beacon St. off to war in 1863.
stops.assetName: Robert Gould Shaw and Massachusetts 54th Regiment Memorial
stops.directionsToNextStop: The Robert Gould Shaw/54th Massachusetts Regiment Memorial is on Beacon Street directly opposite the Massachusetts State House. Cross Beacon Street in front of the Massachusetts State House, near the intersection with Park Street. Turn left on Beacon Street. Turn right on Joy Street. Turn left onto Pinckney Street. George Middleton House is on the right side of the street at 5-7 Pinckney Street. NOTE: This house is a private residence and not open to the public. Please respect the privacy of the homeowners.
stops.audioTranscript:
Welcome to the National Parks of Boston’s Virtual Black Heritage Trail. This tour explores the inspiring history of the free African American community of Beacon Hill in the 19th century, a community that led the city and the nation in the fight against slavery and racial injustice.  
We will be stopping at historic homes, churches, schools, and other important sites as we discuss the lives and legacies of these leaders and activists.  
Together with those that found common cause with them, this community helped turn Boston into a crucial center of the Abolition Movement, the Underground Railroad, and the early struggle for civil rights and equality.  
Facing powerful opposition both within the city and throughout the country, this community persevered, and in doing so, helped further Boston’s reputation as a "Cradle of Liberty" in the ongoing American Revolution.  
Our first stop is The Robert Gould Shaw and Massachusetts 54th Regiment Memorial, which commemorates one of the first African American regiments of the Civil War. Following his Emancipation Proclamation in 1863, President Lincoln called for the raising of Black regiments.  Massachusetts Governor John Andrew soon created the Massachusetts 54th Volunteer Infantry and chose Robert Gould Shaw, the son of prominent abolitionists, to serve as its colonel.  
Notable abolitionists including Frederick Douglass and local leaders such as Lewis Hayden recruited men for the 54th Regiment. Men enlisted from every region of the country, and from as far away as Canada and the Caribbean.
Through their heroic, yet tragic, assault on Fort Wagner, South Carolina on July 18, 1863, in which Shaw and many of his men died, the 54th helped erode Northern public opposition to the use of Black soldiers and inspired the enlistment of more than 180,000 Black men into the United States forces. 
Sergeant William H. Carney, severely injured in the battle, saved the regiment’s flag. For this act of bravery, he became the first African American recipient of the Medal of Honor. 
To commemorate this brave Black regiment, Bostonians chose Augustus St. Gaudens to create this high relief bronze monument, which sits prominently on Beacon Street across from the Massachusetts State House.  
Saint-Gaudens took nearly fourteen years to complete his masterpiece. 
Unveiled on May 31st, 1897, this monument depicts the 54th as they marched down Beacon Street off for war in 1863.
It stands as a powerful testament to the cost of freedom and to the true meaning of the Civil War.

stops.significance:
George Middleton and Louis Glapion began constructing this two-family residence at 5 Pinckney Street in 1786. Finished a year later, this building is believed to be the oldest standing home on Beacon Hill. 
Louis Glapion worked as a hairdresser and may have been from the French West Indies. During the Revolution, George Middleton led a Black militia company called the Bucks of America. While little evidence of this group has survived, they likely guarded the property of Boston merchants during the Revolution. A horse breaker and livery man by profession, Middleton also served in several Black community organizations. He became the third Grand Master of the African Lodge, later known as the Prince Hall Masons. Middleton and others also organized the African Society, a charitable organization dedicated to community service, uplift, and education. As a community leader, George Middleton helped build some of the early institutions and organizations in the long history of Black activism on Beacon Hill.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Facing the George Middleton House, turn left and walk down Pinckney Street. The Phillips School is on the right, at the intersection of Pinckney and Anderson Streets. NOTE: This house is a private residence and not open to the public. Please respect the privacy of the homeowners.
stops.audioTranscript:
Our next stop is the George Middleton House, which takes us right back to the late 1780s in Boston, in the years just after the American Revolution. The Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts had declared slavery “inconsistent” with our State Constitution a few years earlier in 1783.  While Black families had begun settling this north slope of Beacon Hill about a generation before, in the mid-1760s, Middleton’s arrival to this emerging neighborhood signaled a new beginning as he and others in that Revolutionary generation staked their claim in Boston and laid the foundation for the larger abolition and equal rights movements to come.  
George Middleton and Louis Glapion began constructing this two-family residence at 5 Pinckney Street in 1786. Finished a year later, this building is believed to be the oldest standing home on Beacon Hill. 
Louis Glapion worked as a hairdresser and may have been from the French West Indies. Glapion lived and ran his business here until his death in 1813. His wife, Lucy, continued to live here until 1832.
We know a little bit more about George Middleton.  During the Revolution, he led a Black militia company called the Bucks of America. While little evidence of this group has survived, they likely guarded the property of Boston merchants during the Revolution and may have also been known as the "Protectors." Near the close of the Revolution, Governor John Hancock presented Middleton and the Bucks of America with a company flag. According to the historian William Cooper Nell, this banner, now preserved in the collections of the Massachusetts Historical Society, served “as a tribute to their courage and devotion through the struggle.”
A horse breaker and livery man by profession, Middleton also served in several Black community organizations. He became the third Grand Master of the African Lodge, later known as the Prince Hall Masons. In 1796, Middleton and others organized the African Society, a charitable organization dedicated to community service, uplift, and education. He became a licensed teacher in that organization as well.
Middleton married Elsey Marsh in 1781 at Trinity Church and died in 1815, apparently not survived by his wife or children.
As a leader concerned with education, the abolition of slavery, and the needs of his community, George Middleton helped build some of the early institutions and organizations in the long history of Black activism on Beacon Hill.

stops.significance: Built in 1824, this building originally served as the Boston English High School. It became the Phillips Grammar School in 1844, named after Boston’s first mayor, John Phillips. Until 1855, the Phillips School, like most public schools in the city, only educated White students. Black students attended segregated schools nearby, including one in the basement of the African Meeting House and then later at the Abiel Smith School. Equal School Rights activists such as William Cooper Nell, Lewis Hayden, Benjamin Roberts, and others led protests and petition drives that ultimately compelled the state legislature outlaw segregated schools in Massachusetts in 1855. Following this landmark victory, the Phillips School become one of the first public schools in Boston with an interracial student body.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Facing the Phillips School from Pinckney Street, turn left. The John J. Smith House is on the left side of the street at 86 Pinckney Street. NOTE: This house is a private residence and not open to the public. Please respect the privacy of the homeowners.
stops.audioTranscript:
Our next site is the Phillips School. Built in 1824, this building originally served as the Boston English High School. It became the Phillips Grammar School in 1844, named after Boston’s first mayor, John Phillips. 
Until 1855, the Phillips School, like most public schools in the city, only educated White students, a stark reminder of the discrimination faced by Black children and families. Black students attended segregated schools nearby, including one in the basement of the African Meeting House and then later at the Abiel Smith School.
To combat this injustice, Equal School Rights activists such as William Cooper Nell, Lewis Hayden, Benjamin Roberts, and others led protests and petition drives that ultimately compelled the state legislature outlaw segregated schools in Massachusetts in 1855. 
Following this landmark victory, the Phillips School become one of the first public schools in Boston with an interracial student body. 
In 1863, the Phillips School moved to a new building on Phillips Street and became the Wendell Phillips School, named after the famed abolitionist and son of the school’s original namesake. 
In the early 1870s, Elizabeth Smith, daughter of abolitionist John J. Smith, started teaching at the Phillips School, likely becoming the first African American teacher in an integrated Boston public school.

stops.significance: John J. Smith, a barber, community activist, and state legislator, lived in this home from 1878 to 1893. Born free in Richmond, Virginia, Smith moved to Boston in the 1840s. He became a leading community activist and ran a barbershop that became a center for abolitionist activity. Smith played a crucial role in helping Shadrach Minkins, a freedom seeker arrested in Boston under the provisions of the 1850 Fugitive Slave Law. In a daring rescue, Black Bostonians freed Minkins from the courthouse where the slave catchers held him and helped him make his way to freedom in Canada. Smith and his wife, Georgiana, also participated in the equal school rights movements of the 1850s. Their daughter, Elizabeth, became the first person of African descent to teach in an integrated public school in Boston. During the Civil War, Smith recruited for the Black Massachusetts regiments and the 5th Calvary. He later served in the Massachusetts House of Representatives for three terms, as well as on the Boston Common Council.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Facing the John J. Smith House from Pickney Street, turn right. Turn left on to Cedar Lane Way. Turn right onto Mount Vernon Street and carefully cross Charles Street. Charles Street Meeting House is at the intersection of Charles and Mount Vernon Streets.
stops.audioTranscript:
John J. Smith, a barber, community activist, and state legislator, lived in this home from 1878 to 1893.
Born free in Richmond, Virginia, Smith moved to Boston in the 1840s. He became a leading community activist and ran a barbershop that became a center for abolitionist activity. His clients included the abolitionist Senator Charles Sumner, who could often be found at Smith’s barbershop while in town. His shop also reportedly served a rendezvous point for “secret councils” that offered protection and assistance to those escaping slavery on the Underground Railroad.
Smith played a crucial role in helping Shadrach Minkins, a freedom seeker arrested in Boston under the provisions of the 1850 Fugitive Slave Law. In a daring rescue, Black Bostonians freed Minkins from the courthouse where the slave catchers held him. He hid out the rest of the day first in a home on the north slope of Beacon Hill, then just outside the city. Late that night, Smith, along with Lewis Hayden, secretly took Minkins to a safe house in Concord, where he stayed before making the rest of his way to freedom in Canada. 
Smith and his wife Georgiana also participated in the equal school rights movements of the 1850s. Their daughter, Elizabeth, became the first person of African descent to teach in an integrated public school in Boston.
During the Civil War, he recruited for the Black Massachusetts regiments and the 5th Calvary. He later served in the Massachusetts House of Representatives for three terms, as well as on the Boston Common Council where he worked successfully to have the first African American appointed to the Boston police force. Smith died in 1906 while living with his family in Dorchester.

stops.significance: Built in 1807, this building originally housed the Third Baptist Church. In April 1836, member Timothy Gilbert tested the church’s racial segregation policy by inviting several African Americans to join him in his pew. The church immediately expelled Gilbert for this violation. He soon set out with several other members to form the First Free Baptist Church, which became officially recognized in 1839. In 1876, the First African Methodist Episcopal congregation purchased the Charles Street Meeting House. This prompted one historian to note while African Americans once sat in one section of the church, "now they own the building." The Meeting House also served as a forum and gathering place for activists. For example, in 1895 Josephine St. Pierre Ruffin and other Black clubwomen formed the National Federation of Afro-American women, a precursor to the National Association of Colored Women. The AME congregation held services in this location until 1939, becoming the last Black institution to leave Beacon Hill.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Standing with your back to the Charles Street Meeting House on Charles Street, turn left and walk a couple blocks. Turn right on to Revere Street, carefully crossing Charles Street. Turn left on to West Cedar Street. Turn right on to Phillips Street. The Lewis and Harriet Hayden House is on the right at 66 Phillips Street. NOTE: This house is a private residence and not open to the public. Please respect the privacy of the homeowners.
stops.audioTranscript:
Built in 1807, this building originally housed the Third Baptist Church. Like most churches, the segregationist tradition of New England church seating patterns prevailed here. 
In April 1836, however, member Timothy Gilbert tested the church’s racial segregation policy by inviting several African Americans to join him in his pew.  The church immediately expelled Gilbert for this violation.  
He soon set out with several other members to form the First Free Baptist Church. Officially recognized in 1839, this church eventually became Tremont Temple, considered “the first integrated church in America.” Tremont Temple declared that “’all who practice slavery or justify it shall be excluded from the church and its communion.’”  Tremont Temple soon hosted giants in the abolition movement including Frederick Douglass, Sojourner Truth and others. 
In 1876, the First African Methodist Episcopal congregation, earlier located on today’s Anderson Street, purchased the Charles Street Meetinghouse.  This prompted one historian to note that in the early days of the Meeting House, African Americans could only sit in a certain section of the church, but “now they own the building.” 
In addition to religious services, the Charles Street Meeting House served as a forum and gathering place for activists.  For example, on the final day of the 1895 First National Conference of Colored Women of America, Josephine St. Pierre Ruffin and other local Black clubwomen organized a special session at Charles Street A.M.E. Church. Here, delegates from across the United States agreed to form the National Federation of Afro-American women, one of the precursors to the National Association of Colored Women. The AME congregation held services in this location until 1939, even after many of its members had moved to the South End of Boston. It became the last Black institution to leave Beacon Hill. Still called the Charles Street AME Church, it is now located in Roxbury in Boston.

stops.significance: The Lewis and Harriet Hayden House served as the preeminent Underground Railroad safe house in Boston during the 1850s. In the 1840s, the Haydens escaped slavery in Kentucky and eventually settled here. They lived in this house by 1850, operated it as a boardinghouse, and turned it into one of the most documented safe houses in the area. The Haydens notably assisted in high-profile Fugitive Slave Law cases, helping William and Ellen Craft as well as Shadrach Minkins on their journeys to freedom. In addition to their Underground Railroad work, Lewis and Harriet played other prominent roles in the community. Lewis served as Grand Master of the Prince Hall Masons, presided over numerous community meetings, and participated in the Equal Schools movement. During the Civil War, he recruited Black soldiers for the Massachusetts regiments. Following the War, Lewis Hayden served as one of the first Black members of the state legislature and, along with Harriet, lent his support in the fight for women’s suffrage.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Facing the Hayden House, turn left. Walk down Phillips Street. The John Coburn House is to the right facing Phillips Street at the intersection of Irving and Phillips Street. NOTE: This house is a private residence and not open to the public. Please respect the privacy of the homeowners.
stops.audioTranscript:
The Lewis and Harriet Hayden House served as the preeminent Underground Railroad safe house in Boston during the 1850s. In the 1840s, the Haydens escaped slavery in Kentucky and eventually settled here. They lived in this house by 1850, operated as a boardinghouse, and turned it into one of the most documented safe houses in the area. A long-time colleague of the Hayden, Henry Bowditch recalled that their house served as “the temple of refuge for any hunted refugee from Southern slavery.”  
Following the passage of the 1850 Fugitive Slave Law, Bostonians created their third and final Vigilance Committee, an organization dedicated to fugitive assistance. As one of the most active members of this committee, Lewis sheltered and assisted scores of freedom seekers. The Haydens provided shelter, clothing, carriages, and fare to get people out of the city and further North to freedom. 
In 1850, the Haydens sheltered the famous couple William and Ellen Craft who had escaped from slavery in Georgia through an elaborate disguise and story. The light-skinned Ellen dressed in men’s clothing and “passed” as a white male slaveholder traveling North by train and ship with her trusted “slave” William. In October 1850, slave catchers came looking for the couple in Boston’s first test of the new Fugitive Slave Law.  According to William Craft, “Lewis Hayden and I had a keg of gunpowder under his house ...with a fuse attached ready to light it should any attempt be made to capture us.” Given all of the abolitionist hostility and threats to their safety, the slave catchers abandoned their pursuit of the Crafts.  A journalist later wrote that the slave catcher called off  his pursuit because he “knew that the road to hell lay over Lewis Hayden’s threshold; and the cost to him would be rather more than the Slave Power would be ready to make up to him.” 
In addition to protecting the Crafts, Lewis also played a crucial role in other high-profile Fugitive Slave Law cases in the city.  On February 15, 1851, slave catchers arrested Shadrach Minkins who had escaped from Virginia months earlier. Within three hours of the arrest, Hayden led a group of Black men in a daring courthouse rescue, freed Minkins from his captors, and successfully got him out of the city and further on the Underground Railroad network to Canada. In 1854, Hayden and others attempted to rescue Anthony Burns from federal custody at the same courthouse. Unfortunately, they failed, and authorities soon returned Burns to the South under heavy martial guard.  
In addition to his Underground Railroad work, Lewis played other prominent roles in his community. He served as Grand Master of the Prince Hall Masons, presided over numerous community meetings and participated in the Equal Schools movement. In the late 1850s, he began serving as Messenger to the Secretary of State, a politically appointed position, likely making him one of the first Black state employees.
During the Civil War, he recruited Black soldiers for the Massachusetts civil war regiments. Following the War, Hayden served as one of the first Black members of the state legislature and lent his support in the fight for women’s suffrage.
Harriet outlived her husband by four years.  When she passed away in 1893, she left her estate, valued at $5000, to Harvard University to establish the Lewis and Harriet Hayden Scholarship for Black students wishing to attend the Medical School.

stops.significance: Clothes dealer and community activist John P. Coburn and his family lived at this home beginning in 1844. In addition to his clothing shop, limited evidence suggests that Coburn may have ran a gaming house for wealthy Bostonians in his house. Coburn served as the treasurer of the New England Freedom Association, an organization dedicated to assisting freedom seekers who escaped slavery and came to Boston on the Underground Railroad. In 1851, authorities arrested, though later acquitted, Coburn for his alleged role in aiding in the courthouse rescue of Shadrach Minkins. Along with other community leaders in the 1850s, Coburn founded the Massasoit Guards, an unsanctioned Black militia. Militia groups such the Massasoit Guards can be considered precursors to the Black Civil War regiments, including the famous 54th Massachusetts. Coburn died in 1873 and his home passed to his son Wendell, whose widow, Mary, lived in the house until the turn of the twentieth century.
stops.directionsToNextStop: With back to John Coburn house, turn right to the intersection of Phillips and Irving Streets. Turn left down Irving Street. At Cambridge Street, turn right. Turn right on to Joy Street. Turn right at Smith Court. Smith Court Residences are on the right. NOTE: These houses are private residences and not open to the public. Please respect the privacy of the homeowners.
stops.audioTranscript:
Born in Boston in the early 1800s, clothes dealer and community activist John P. Coburn and his family lived at this home beginning in 1844. In addition to his clothing shop, limited evidence suggests that Coburn may have ran a gaming house for wealthy Bostonians in his house. However, his community activism is far better documented.
Coburn served as the treasurer of the New England Freedom Association, an organization dedicated to assisting freedom seekers who escaped slavery and came to Boston on the Underground Railroad. Formed in the early 1840s, this group sought “to extend a helping hand to all who may bid adieu to whips and chains, and by the welcome light of the North Star, reach a haven where they can be protected from the grasp of the man-stealer.” 
In 1851, authorities arrested, though later acquitted, Coburn for his alleged role in aiding in the courthouse rescue of Shadrach Minkins. Witness reported seeing him at the courthouse “’making inflammatory remarks shortly before the rescue began.’” 
Along with other community leaders in the 1850s, Coburn founded the Massasoit Guards, an unsanctioned Black militia. Though state officials ignored their requests for official recognition and support, the Massasoit Guards continued to operate as a force for community self-defense. Militia groups such the Massasoit Guards can be considered precursors to the Black Civil War regiments, including the famous 54th Massachusetts.
Coburn died in 1873 and his home passed to his son Wendell, whose widow, Mary, lived in the house until the turn of the twentieth century.

stops.significance: As home to the African Meeting House and the Abiel Smith School, Smith Court served as a vital center of African American life and culture for much of the nineteenth and earlier twentieth century in Boston. The residences along Smith Court also provide a valuable window into the lives of the African Americans who called this neighborhood home. Residents of 3 Smith Court, James Scott and William Cooper Nell, both sheltered freedom seekers in the 1850s. In 1849, George Washington purchased 5 Smith Court. He served as deacon of the First Independent Baptist Church at the African Meeting House. Built in 1799, 7A Smith Court is the only surviving example of the early homes that lined Holmes Alley. African American chimneysweep and clothing dealer Joseph Scarlett owned 7 Smith Court, 7A Smith Court, and 2 Smith Court. Living in 2 Smith Court, Scarlett rented out the other properties. By the time of his death in 1898, Scarlett owned 15 different properties in Boston, Cambridge, and Charlestown.
stops.directionsToNextStop: With back to the residences, walk directly ahead to the path between two brick buildings. The Abiel Smith School is on the left and is operated by the Museum of African American History. Walk down the stairs to the entrance of the Museum.
stops.audioTranscript:
As home to the African Meeting House and the Abiel Smith School, Smith Court served as a vital center of African American life and culture for much of the nineteenth and earlier twentieth century in Boston. The residences along Smith Court also provide a valuable window into the lives of the African Americans who called this neighborhood home.
For example, 3 Smith Court has a long association of African American occupants as well as significant activists in Boston. James Scott, the longest resident of 3 Smith Court, lived here for nearly 50 years. Born in Virginia, Scott worked as a clothing dealer in Boston. In 1851, local authorities arrested, though later acquitted, Scott for his alleged role in the rescue of freedom seeker Shadrach Minkins from the Boston courthouse. Though his involvement in the Shadrach rescue is unclear, Scott did assist other freedom seekers at his home, including Henry Jackson and his family as they made their way to freedom on the Underground Railroad in 1856. For most of the 1850s, William Cooper Nell also resided at 3 Smith Court. One of the most prominent community activists, Nell provided crucial leadership in the abolition movement and the struggle for equal education. With the publication of his book "Colored Patriots of the American Revolution," Nell became one of the first published African American historians.  Like Scott, he also sheltered freedom seekers at his home on Smith Court. 
In 1849, George Washington purchased 5 Smith Court. Born in Massachusetts in 1795, Washington worked as a bootblack and waiter.  He also served as deacon at the First Independent Baptist Church at the African Meeting House. Washington and his wife Rachel had ten children. Although he died in 1871, this house remained in the family until 1917. 
7 Smith Court served as rental property for Joseph Scarlett, an African American chimneysweep and clothing dealer.  He mainly rented to other African Americans including laborers and mariners that rarely stayed longer than three years at this property. 
Built in 1799, 7A Smith Court is the only surviving example of the early homes that lined Holmes Alley. This became another rental property for Scarlett in 1858.  
2 Smith Court, built in 1853, served as the home and investment property for Scarlett as well. Prior to its construction, an earlier home stood on this site owned by William Henry, an African American tailor. Henry, his family, as well as some tenants lived here. Scarlett purchased the property in 1852, built this home, and lived here for most of the 1860s. By the time of his death in 1898, Scarlett owned fifteen different properties in Boston, Cambridge, and Charlestown. In his will, Scarlett left bequests to the African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church and to the Home for Aged Colored Women.

stops.significance: The Abiel Smith School opened in 1835 and served as the segregated public school for Black children in Boston for twenty years. Prior to this, Black students attended school at the African School on the ground floor of the African Meeting House. Overcrowded and underfunded, the Smith School became the focal point in the Black community’s ongoing struggle for Equal School Rights in the 1840s and 1850s. William Cooper Nell led the charge against the segregated Smith School, facing opposition from Whites and well as from some in his own community. Over the course of more than 15 years, through a series of local petitions, protests, court cases, and ultimately a state-wide petition, Nell and others successfully convinced the legislature to outlaw public school segregation in 1855. Today, the Smith School houses the Museum Store and exhibition galleries of the Museum of African American History.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Exit the Museum at the Abiel Smith School. Walk up the stairs and directly ahead is the African Meeting House.
stops.audioTranscript:
The Abiel Smith School opened in 1835 and served as the segregated public school for Black children in Boston for twenty years. Prior to this, Black students attended school at the African School on the ground floor of the African Meeting House.  
Overcrowded and underfunded, the Smith School became the focal point in the Black community’s ongoing struggle for Equal School Rights in the 1840s and 50s.  
William Cooper Nell, who as student at the African School realized the inequality of segregated education, vowed at an early age to        “hasten the day when the color of the skin would be no barrier to equal school rights.” As an adult, he led the charge against the segregated Smith School, facing opposition from Whites and well as from some in his own community. Over the course of more than fifteen years, through a series of local petitions, protests, court cases, and ultimately a state-wide petition, Nell and others successfully convinced the legislature to outlaw public school segregation in 1855.  
On the day before the first day of school that year, Nell, then living at 3 Smith Court, recalled seeing a young Black student walk past the Smith School. “Good bye forever colored school!,” the student said, “Tomorrow we are like the other Boston boys.”
Following this landmark victory, the Smith School closed briefly then later reopened as an integrated primary school for a time. It also became a storage facility for the city, as well as a home to several veterans’ posts.  
Today, the Smith School houses the Museum Store and exhibition galleries of the Museum of African American History.

stops.significance: Built in 1806, the Meeting House stands as the oldest surviving Black church structure in the nation. It first served as the home for the First African Baptist Church. It also housed the African School for a number of years before the Smith School opened next door, and it hosted numerous community lectures, celebrations, and adult education classes. The Meeting House also served as a gathering space for social activism. Maria Stewart, William Cooper Nell, Lewis Hayden, John Smith, John Coburn, and others used its platform to fight for equal school rights, the end of slavery, and for civil rights. During the Civil War, the Meeting House became a recruitment center for the MA 54th Regiment. A Black church and community center until the end of the 1800s, it became a synagogue in 1904. In 1972, the Meeting House was purchased by the Museum of African American History, who continues to own and operate it today.
stops.audioTranscript:
We conclude our virtual tour here at the African Meeting House, a fitting location, as this place was such powerful center of African American community life and culture in 19th century Boston.  
Built in 1806, the Meeting House served as the home for the First African Baptist Church, originally headed by Reverend Thomas Paul, a key leader and activist in the community. 
It also housed the African School for a number of years before the Smith School opened next door, and it hosted numerous community lectures, celebrations, and adult education classes.  
The Meeting House also served as gathering space for social activism. This is where you joined with William Cooper Nell as he advocated for Equal School Rights. This is where Lewis Hayden, John Smith, John Coburn, and others protested the Fugitive Slave Law and planned how to assist freedom seekers that came to Boston on the Underground Railroad. This is where you came in the early 1830s to hear Maria Stewart call for the end of slavery and for equal rights for women. This is where the Massachusetts General Colored Association came together to fight for the end of slavery and discrimination throughout the country. It is where William Lloyd Garrison formed the New England Antislavery Society, whose principles he said would quote “shake the nation by their mighty power.” It also served as a recruitment center for the 54th Regiment.
In his recruitment speech for the 54th, Frederick Douglass said "... We can get at the throat of treason and slavery through the State of Massachusetts. She was first in the War of Independence; first to break the chains of her slaves; first to make the black man equal before the law; first to admit colored children to her common schools, and she was first to answer with her blood the alarm cry of the nation, when its capital was menaced by rebels. You know her patriotic governor, and you know Charles Summer. I need not add more. Massachusetts now welcomes you to arms as soldiers."
This is such a ringing endorsement of the central role played by Boston in the fight against slavery and racial injustice...so much of which emanated from this neighborhood, from this community, and from within the walls of the African Meeting House.
The Meeting House continued to serve as a Black church and community center until the end of the 1800s. It became a synagogue in 1904. In 1972, the Meeting House was purchased by the Museum of African American History, who continues to own and operate it today.  
In 1980, Boston African American National Historic Site was created as a partner with the Museum to keep these important sites preserved and protected, and to keep these crucial stories of our ongoing American Revolution alive.  
Thank you for joining us for this virtual tour of the Black Heritage Trail.

images.title: Black Heritage Trail® Self-Guided Tour
images.altText: Alley with a 3-story red brick building on the left that has tall windows and homes on the right.
images.caption: Smith Court is home to three stops on the Black Heritage Trail®.

data.title: Black Jack Ruts Audio Tour
data.description: Welcome to the Ivan Boyd Memorial Prairie Preserve and the Black Jack Ruts. Head out on the trail through the woods and over the small creek to the prairie. From there you can walk a gravel trail that is easy walking and will let you experience up close and in person several very impressive wagon ruts created by heavy traffic of mostly freight wagons headed to Santa Fe or returning to Westport or Franklin or merchants along the Missouri River.

stops.significance: Stop Number 1, Welcome.
stops.assetName: Black Jack Ruts Audio Tour Stop 1
stops.audioTranscript: Welcome to the Ivan Boyd Memorial Prairie Preserve and the Black Jack Ruts.  Head out on the trail through the woods and over the small creek to the prairie.  From there you can walk a gravel trail that is easy walking and will let you experience up close and in person several very impressive wagon ruts created by heavy traffic of mostly freight wagons headed to Santa Fe or returning to Westport or Franklin or merchants along the Missouri River.

stops.significance: Stop 2, 2.	First Rut and Exhibits
stops.assetName: Black Jack Ruts Audio Tour Stop 2
stops.audioTranscript: Standing in the circle looking up the hill from the two information panels you will see the expanse of this native prairie.  Most of this prairie has never been plowed or cultivated.  To your right is one of the main wagon ruts at this site.  This one is heading down hill towards you and passes to your right and into the woods to the north.  This portion of the trail had been obscured by trees, vines, and brambles for the past 80 years and has only recently been uncovered by removing the trees and brush.  The wagons would have been crossing Grindstone Creek to the north of present-day highway US 56.  From here continue to Audio Stop #3 in the middle of the ruts.

stops.significance: Stop 3, Middle of Ruts
stops.assetName: Black Jack Ruts Audio Tour Stop 3
stops.audioTranscript: You are standing in the bottom of the middle rut in this prairie.  This is the widest and deepest of the 5 main ruts.  A layer of sandstone uphill from here seeps water much of the year and so the bottom of the ruts is usually damp and muddy.  We constructed a rock path to cross them.  From here, follow the trail up the hill to the south.

stops.significance: Stop 4, Top of Hill
stops.assetName: Black Jack Ruts Audio Tour Stop 4
stops.audioTranscript: Running parallel on your right is the fifth main rut.  It is less impressive but still larger and deeper than most of the other ruts that can be found along the trail to Santa Fe.  In the growing season (April-October) many species and colors of native prairie wildflowers can be found blooming along this trail.

stops.significance: Stop 5, Stone Marker
stops.assetName: Black Jack Ruts Audio Tour Stop 5
stops.audioTranscript: This may look like an authentic marker to show the way along the trail, but no such markers were ever placed along the route.  This stone was placed here by the previous owner, Russell Hays in 1965.  As you look down the ruts to the northwest look at the ridge on the far horizon.  That ridge is the beginning of “The Narrows”.  Continue on to trail marker #6 for more information.

stops.significance: Stop 6, Curve in the Trail
stops.assetName: Black Jack Ruts Audio Tour Stop 6
stops.audioTranscript: From this spot is a great view of these impressive ruts as they go downhill towards Grindstone Creek.  There are at least 5 other much shallower ruts here that can only be seen after the prairie has been burned in the spring.  The Narrows was a ridge that allowed the wagons to safely navigate between tributaries that either flowed to the Marais des Cygnes River to the south or to the Wakarusa River to the north.  The Narrows curves to the northwest and west about 9 miles to Willow Springs.  From there the prairie flattened out onto a broad plain to points further west, like Council Grove.

images.title: Black Jack Ruts trail
images.altText: A narrow path winds through a field of grass.
images.caption: Take the Black Jack Ruts Audio Tour.

data.title: Black Sand Basin
data.description: A thermal area west of the Old Faithful developed area that has chromatic and opalescent hot springs and a geyser that frequently erupts right at the edge of the river flowing through the area.

stops.audioTranscript:
Welcome to Black Sand Basin, named for the sand formed from black volcanic glass, or obsidian, that covers much of the area. This relatively small thermal group on the banks of Iron Spring Creek features some of the most splendid hot springs in Yellowstone. 

Please note: Thermal activity occurs throughout this area. Stay on the boardwalk at all times.

Because of the dynamic nature of the features along this tour, you may complete the tour in as little as a half-hour, or be out for an hour or more. Before heading out, a few safety notes:

It can be windy, so cinch down your hats and secure personal items.

Stay on the boardwalks and established trails at all times. Superheated water is just below a thin crust throughout the basin. Besides the high chance of breaking through the crust and causing bodily injury or death, leaving the trail can damage hydrothermal features—ruining the experience for everyone.

Boardwalks can be slippery when wet or covered in snow.

Watch for wildlife and maintain the minimum safe distance of 25 yards (2 bus-lengths) from any wildlife—and 100 yards (8 bus-lengths) from bears or wolves.

Ready? Head on to the next stop: Opalescent Pool. As you walk along Iron Spring Creek (commonly referred to as Iron Creek), notice the orange bacterial mats in the runoff channels. Members of the 1871 Hayden Survey named the creek for what they thought were deposits of iron oxide.

The park’s hydrothermal system would not exist without the underlying partially molten magma body that releases tremendous heat. The system also requires water, such as ground water from the mountains, and snow and rain that slowly percolate through layers of permeable rock riddled with cracks.

Opalescent Pool is a good example of a hydrothermal feature altered by a natural flux in the interplay of heat and water over time. This pool may have originated as an active, boiling spring, but these days it has no hot-water source of its own. Instead, it is filled with runoff flowing from nearby Spouter Geyser, and the cooler water creates the right conditions for the milky, opal-like color caused by fine particles of silica suspended in the water.

Just across Iron Creek from the boardwalk platform, Cliff Geyser is an example of a fountain geyser: it erupts from a pool instead of from a cone (like Old Faithful). 

Add pressure and constrictions to heat and water, and you have all the ingredients for a geyser. A constriction in the underground plumbing causes pressure to build up until it is released in an eruption. Cliff Geyser’s eruption cycle begins with an empty crater and minor eruptions lasting only seconds. The crater slowly fills and, at a critical point, the confined bubbles lift the water above the surface vent, causing the geyser to splash or overflow in bursts as high as 40 feet (12 m) for 5 to 15 minutes. The eruption stops when the water reservoir is depleted or when the system cools.

As you view Cliff Geyser, notice the water level in its crater: Is it filling with water, or is it empty and quiet? What you observe above the surface can tell you what’s happening below. Intervals between eruptions can range from a matter of hours to several weeks or even to many months.

Emerald Pool is a hot spring that was once deep green in color, a result of the combination of the blue of its water and the yellow-orange cyanobacteria lining the crater walls. Cyanobacteria are a type of thermophile, or heat-loving organism, that can survive and thrive in the extreme environments found in and around thermal features throughout Yellowstone.

Colors, locations, and types of thermophiles vary, depending in part on water temperature. The brownish hues present today suggest a change in conditions over time. What changed? If you guessed water temperature, you are correct! As Emerald Pool’s water temperatures have decreased over time, the pool has turned more brownish than green, indicating the presence of a type of thermophile found in cooler hot springs and runoff channels.

Rainbow Pool is a large pool with rainbow-like ribbons of color around its edge. This hot spring was once a powerful geyser. In 1938, Rainbow erupted several times per day to a height of 80 feet (24 m). It has had other periods of activity, most recently in late 1996, when some eruptions reached a height of more than 100 feet (30 m). 1996 is the last year Rainbow Pool erupted.

Sunset Lake is the largest pool in Black Sand Basin; it is actually a geyser and has been known to erupt. It continues to have small and infrequent eruptions that can go unnoticed because of the heavy steam over the water. Its largest known eruptions occurred in 1981 and 1984 and reached up to 35 feet (11 m).

We hope you enjoyed exploring this small group of colorful hot springs and geysers and found many reasons to preserve and protect the resources of this planet—from the geysers and hot springs of Yellowstone to the nature near your home.

images.title: Cliff Geyser
images.altText: Steam and water erupt out of a rimmed crater at the edge of a small creek.
images.caption: Cliff Geyser erupting

data.title: Boat through Glacier Bay!
data.description: Follow a journey into Glacier Bay, with locations and descriptions hand-picked by Glacier Bay Park Rangers.

stops.significance: Icy Strait is the body of water just south of Glacier Bay's entrance and Sitakaday Narrows (the next stop)
stops.directionsToNextStop: From Icy Strait, the entrance to Glacier Bay is to the north, between two points of land called Gustavus Point (eastern shore) and Carolus Point (western shore).

stops.significance: Bartlett Cove is the geographic headquarters for Glacier Bay National Park and Preserve.
stops.directionsToNextStop: On the shore of Bartlett Cove sits the Huna Tribal House, your next stop.

stops.significance: The Huna Tribal House memorializes the clan houses that once lined the shores of present day Bartlett Cove, now the site of National Park Service headquarters in Glacier Bay.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From Bartlett Cove and the Huna Tribal House, the Beardslee Islands lie directly north.

stops.significance: The Beardslee Islands are a grouping of islands just to the north of Bartlett Cove and the Gustavus mainland.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From the Beardslee Islands, head north toward the heart of Glacier Bay. The narrow passageway upon which you enter the Bay is known as Sitakaday Narrows.

stops.significance: Welcome to Glacier Bay! Sitakaday Narrows is the entrance to the Bay. With strong currents passing through here twice a day with the tides, this area is a productive place to find wildlife such as seabirds, sea otters, and humpback whales.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Sitakaday Narrows marks the start of your journey into the heart of Glacier Bay. When traveling across open water, keep an eye out for whale spouts breaking the surface of the water. If navigating near the shore, look for wildlife like bears or wolves cruising the shoreline! Your next stop is South Marble Island, a rocky island in the middle of Glacier Bay.

stops.significance: South Marble Island is a wildlife hotspot! Steller Sea Lions and many species of seabirds await you here. Even humpback whales come to the Marble Islands to feed near their shores.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From South Marble Island, Glacier Bay splits into two arms. The east arm (your next stop) is known as Muir Inlet, while the west arm branches off to the northwest, and is a larger inlet than Muir.

stops.significance: Known as Glacier Bay's East Arm, Muir Inlet is a lesser-traveled arm of Glacier Bay. Named for the once tremendous Muir Glacier, that glacier now sits aground at the end of the long inlet.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From the opening to Muir Inlet, head west toward Glacier Bay's West Arm.

stops.significance: As you motor up Glacier Bay, keep an eye on the shorelines for wildlife activity. One charismatic member of Alaska's wildlife family is the brown bear! Brown bears in Glacier Bay are often seen flipping rocks in the intertidal zone to search for food.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Tlingit Point is located roughly between the East and West Arms of Glacier Bay. Head west up the bay to continue the tour.

stops.significance: The sea otter. Most likely you've already seen several of this marine mammal floating in the waters of Glacier Bay. Sea otters are found in bays and protected inlets throughout the park, such as Hugh Miller Inlet.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From Hugh Miller Inlet, continue northwest up Glacier Bay. Look due north from Hugh Miller Inlet to see your next destination, a smooth rocky outcropping known as gloomy knob.

stops.significance: Gloomy knob is a geologic masterpiece, and a great place to spot mountain goats!
stops.directionsToNextStop: From Gloomy Knob, continue northwest up the west arm of Glacier Bay.

stops.significance: Now that you are nearing the upper reaches of Glacier Bay, evidence of glaciers should start becoming more apparent. What makes a glacier? There are many ingredients to create these rivers of ice, click explore to learn more.
stops.assetName: Glacier Recipe: What Makes a Glacier in the Bay?
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue northwest up Glacier Bay to your next stop, Russell Island.

stops.significance: Russell Island sits in the intersection of several glacial fjords. From here, Lamplugh, Reid, Johns Hopkins, Margerie, and Grand Pacific Glaciers are a short distance away.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From Russell Island, head north. You may be seeing chunks of ice floating in the water, this is a clue to your next destination, Tarr Inlet.

stops.significance: Tarr Inlet marks the entrance to the body of water which holds Margerie and Grand Pacific Glaciers. Keep an eye out for floating icebergs!
stops.directionsToNextStop: Welcome to Tarr Inlet, have you spotted any floating ice yet? Head northwest to the end point of this inlet, where you will soon see the gleaming ice of Margerie Glacier.

stops.significance: Glaciers are moving rivers of ice, so what happens when that ice meets the sea? Action!
stops.assetName: What is Calving? In Glacier Bay
stops.directionsToNextStop: From the end of Tarr Inlet, your next two destinations are within eyesight. The magnificent Margerie Glacier and historic Grand Pacific Glacier lie before you.

stops.significance: A crown jewel of Glacier Bay, Margerie Glacier drops ice into the bay with regularity. Soak in the view, and keep your ears open too!
stops.directionsToNextStop: From Margerie Glacier, turn north to see the decaying remains of Grand Pacific Glacier. Now covered in rock and glacial till, the Grand Pacific Glacier can be hard to spot from afar. It sits at the northern limit of Glacier Bay and Tarr Inlet.

stops.significance: The final stop in the tour, Grand Pacific Glacier once filled the entirety of Glacier Bay no more than 200 years ago. Today, it is covered in rock and glacial till, and extends many miles into a vast icefield.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Now that you've explored the glaciers of Tarr Inlet, head south out of the inlet the direction you came.

stops.significance: A colony of black-legged kittiwakes has occasionally chosen to nest just south of Margerie Glacier's face. When the glacier calves, fish and other aquatic life can be stunned from the shockwave, leaving easy pickings for the kittiwakes.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Head south out of Tarr Inlet to your next destination.

stops.significance: As you travel through Glacier Bay, know that thousands of years of glaciation formed the landscape around you.
stops.assetName: Glacial Landscape Features in Glacier Bay
stops.directionsToNextStop: Your next stop is Mount Cooper. On clear days, it towers above Lamplugh Glacier, southeast of Johns Hopkins Inlet.

stops.significance: Mount Cooper is a picturesque mountain rising high above Lamplugh Glacier, at the point between Lamplugh and Johns Hopkins Inlet. Even if you can't see its summit on a cloudy day, look for hanging alpine glaciers on its steep slopes.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From Mount Cooper, head west toward Johns Hopkins Inlet. In Johns Hopkins Inlet, a critical population of harbor seals live and breed each year.

stops.significance: Harbor seals have raise their pups in narrow Johns Hopkins Inlet each year in the early summer. Harbor seals are one of just a few animals on earth that rely heavily upon floating icebergs to rear their pups on.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Head west and then southwest into Johns Hopkins Inlet to your next destination. NOTE: Johns Hopkins Inlet is closed to ALL vessels from 5/1 to 6/30 each year.

stops.significance: The entryway to Johns Hopkins Inlet, Jaw Point offers a stunning view of Johns Hopkins Glacier as you round the point.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From Jaw Point, it is approximately 5 miles southeast to the face of Johns Hopkins Glacier, your next stop. NOTE: Johns Hopkins Inlet is CLOSED to all vessel traffic from May 1 through June 30, and a speed limit remains in effect from July 1 through August 31 to protect sensitive harbor seal pupping grounds.

stops.significance: This rock-streaked tidewater glacier has undergone many changes over the years. Stunning mountains surround you in Johns Hopkins Inlet, many with remnant alpine glaciers high in the mountain peaks.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From Johns Hopkins Glacier, head out of Johns Hopkins Inlet the way you came and turn right, toward Lamplugh Glacier, your next destination.

stops.significance: As you view floating ice and the mighty rivers of ice that reach down from Glacier Bay's mountainsides, a common question might be, why is the ice a vivid blue color? Read on to find out.
stops.assetName: Why is the Ice Blue? In Glacier Bay
stops.directionsToNextStop: From here, your next stop is blue Lamplugh Glacier, due south.

stops.significance: Like its neighbor Reid, Lamplugh Glacier slopes down from the Brady Icefield before reaching Glacier Bay.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From Lamplugh Glacier, head southeast to glimpse the final glacier of this tour, known as Reid Glacier.

stops.significance: This inlet is home to Reid Glacier, a gently sloping glacier which descends from the massive Brady Icefield.
stops.directionsToNextStop: After Reid Inlet, head southeast down Glacier Bay's west arm the way you entered. Keep an eye on the shorelines for wildlife!

stops.significance: Plant succession is a critical element of Glacier Bay's scientific story. As glaciers recede and melt, what happens to this newly exposed land? And how fast will vegetation retake the new ground? Scientists and ecologists have looked to answer these questions since the park's de-glaciation.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue southeast out of Glacier Bay's west arm.

stops.significance: Stumps as old as 9,000 years still reside in Glacier Bay. These stumps have survived multiple periods of glaciation, and are visible as you pass through Whidbey Passage. Unassuming on the shore, look for broken stumps sitting along the rocky beach.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue south, down Glacier Bay, to your final stop in this tour.

stops.significance: The mighty humpback whale. Endangered humpback whales have been studied at Glacier Bay for decades, leading to one of the longest-running whale monitoring programs for this species.
stops.directionsToNextStop: This concludes this virtual tour of Glacier Bay. There are many more places to explore in the NPS app outside of this tour, go to the map to see more! Thanks for visit, and we can't wait to see you again.

images.title: Tour Boat in Johns Hopkins Inlet
images.altText: A tour boat is dwarfed by steep rugged icy mountains, while a glacier pours into water, overcast day
images.caption: See magnificent views of a bay that was covered in ice less than 150 years ago.

data.title: Boca Trail
data.description: Come take a hike along the Boca Trail, a 2 mile loop at the base of Capulin Volcano! Most of the lava that erupted from Capulin Volcano erupted from vents in the boca on the western side of the cinder cone. Lava features including levees, lava lakes, and collapsed lava tubes can be seen along this trail.

stops.assetName: Collapsed Lava Tube at Capulin Volcano

data.title: Bodie Island Lighthouse Area
data.description: The Bodie Island Lighthouse area is a great place to explore, and will quickly expose you to the amazing nature and human history of the Outer Banks.

stops.significance: The Bodie Island Visitor Center, inside the historic lighthouse keeper's quarters, provides great insight into the life of the lighthouse keepers.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Exit the visitor center, and proceed to the base of the Bodie Island Lighthouse.
stops.audioTranscript:
Welcome to Cape Hatteras National Seashore, a part of the National Park System, where the rich natural and cultural resources of the Outer Banks of North Carolina are preserved and protected.

At the northern end of Cape Hatteras National Seashore stands the Bodie Island Lighthouse, which is open for climbing from the third Friday in April through Columbus Day. Near the lighthouse are a visitor center, a pair of short trails, and a swim beach that has lifeguards on duty during the summer. Visiting all of the sites on this tour will take about an hour and covers about 1-1/2 miles on the ground and a 1-mile drive between the Bodie Island Lighthouse grounds and Coquina Beach Day Use Area.

The Bodie Island Visitor Center is a great place to start any visit to this part of the seashore. National Park Service rangers are stationed here to answer any questions you have. You can also purchase your tickets to climb the lighthouse and purchase off-road vehicle permits. You can pick up a free beach fire permit and you can explore the selection of items for sale in the gift store. Restroom facilities are located outside at the start of the Bodie Island Nature Trail.

This was once the living quarters of the lighthouse keepers. Take a moment and ponder the life of a lighthouse keeper, and what it might have been like to live in a remote area before bridges connected the islands and tourism brought thousands of visitors to the area. What do you think some of the challenges would have been living in an isolated place? Explore this site within the app to discover more.

If you are visiting between the third Friday in April and Columbus Day, and you want to climb the lighthouse, be sure to purchase tickets here. When you are ready, exit the visitor center to head on to the next stop.

stops.significance: The iconic Bodie Island Lighthouse was completed in 1872 and has become a important landmark in the Outer Banks.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Walk back to the parking lot, and head to the white restroom building where the Bodie Island Nature Trail begins.
stops.audioTranscript:
Upon exiting the visitor center, take a moment to study the exterior of Bodie Island Lighthouse from bottom to top. What do you notice about the base of the lighthouse and how you enter it? What features stand out to you as you examine the tower itself? What do you see when you look at the lantern room at the top of the lighthouse?

From this location at the base of the lighthouse, can you see the ocean from here? Why do you think a lighthouse was built here?

Be sure to explore the site information in this app to discover the history and details of this lighthouse.

Climbing the lighthouse is not a part of this tour, so if you are climbing the lighthouse, please enjoy the experience and then continue this tour after the climb. When you are ready to continue, follow the brick path toward the Bodie Island Visitor Center and follow the path to the right around the visitor center, along the parking lot, to the wooden boardwalk near the restroom facilities.

stops.significance: The accessible Bodie Island Nature Trail provides some of the best views of the Bodie Island Lighthouse while allowing you to explore the unique ecosystem of the tidal marshes.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Head back to the parking lot, and walk to the northern end of the parking lot where the Off-Island Trail begins.
stops.audioTranscript:
The quarter-mile-long Bodie Island Nature Trail provides a wonderful, accessible way to experience the natural world of the Outer Banks, a world that changes with the seasons. This area is part of the Atlantic Flyway, a major migratory route of birds moving between Canada and the Caribbean.

During the fall, winter, and spring seasons, watch for the various migrating waterfowl. Each season brings a different suite of birds that are moving through the area. During the summer season, keep an eye out for the different species that make use of the freshwater and marshy surroundings, including snakes, crabs, fish, and birds.

As you move along the boardwalk, take note of the tall stands of Phragmites, an invasive species that you can find across the seashore and the eastern United States of America. Phragmites is a threat to this ecosystem and the native species that live here. Why might that be the case? What do you notice about this plant that might cause it to be a problem for other species, plants and animals alike? Explore the section on Phragmites in the site information of this app to learn more about this critical resource issue.

stops.significance: Nature trail that provides great views of the rich soundside ecosystem.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Return to the Bodie Island visitor center, and travel back down the road to Highway 12.  Cross the highway and enter the Coquina Beach parking lot.
stops.audioTranscript:
This quarter-mile trail provides a different experience than the Bodie Island Nature Trail. Instead of heading to a freshwater pond, this trail takes you right to the edge of the Roanoke Sound, part of the shallow body of water that separates the barrier islands of the Outer Banks from the mainland of North Carolina.

As you head along the trail, listen closely for bird calls. About halfway along the trail, there is a bridge over a small creek. Look in the creek for signs of life. If you are lucky, you may catch a glimpse of a blue crab.

At the end of the trail, where you see a private hunting lodge across the channel of water, you can take in views of the sound. What do you notice about the sound? Which direction is the water flowing? What differences do you see between the freshwater ponds at the end of the Bodie Island Nature Trail and this body of water?

When you are ready to continue the tour, return to the Bodie Island Visitor Center, travel back down Bodie Island Lighthouse Road, carefully cross North Carolina-12, and head over to the bathhouse at the Coquina Beach Day Use Area.

stops.significance: A place to access the beaches of Cape Hatteras National Seashore.  Lifeguards provided in the summer months.
stops.directionsToNextStop: To return to the start of the tour, cross highway 12 and return to the Bodie Island Visitor Center.
stops.audioTranscript:
The final stop for this tour is the Coquina Beach Day Use Area. From the accessible Coquina Beach Bathhouse, take the pedestrian boardwalk out onto the beach to get a close-up view of the Atlantic Ocean.

Be sure to look back toward the island to see the Bodie Island Lighthouse. Imagine being aboard a ship in the ocean during a calm day, during a stormy day, or during a stormy night. If you were on that ship, how important would that lighthouse be to you?

Now, take a moment to feel the sand and look at the grains. Most of the sand is made up of quartz from the Appalachian Mountains, although that’s not all that is in the sand. The coarser, orange grains are tiny bits of seashells that came from the ocean floor, and over time have been ground up. If you happen to have picked up sand with the fine, black particles, then you’ve picked up magnetite (and some semi-precious minerals) that also made there way here from the Appalachian Mountains!

Thanks for going on this tour of Bodie Island Lighthouse Area. We hope you enjoyed this tour, discovered something new about Cape Hatteras National Seashore, and are ready to experience all that this special place has to offer.
