data.title: Boston Harbor Islands National and State Park: Georges Island Tour
data.description: Welcome to Georges Island! This self-guided audio tour will help acquaint you with the history and function of the Island and Fort Warren. This audio tour is presented by the Boston Harbor Islands National and State Park partnership, including the National Park Service, the Massachusetts Department of Conservation & Recreation, and Boston Harbor Now.

park.fullName: Boston Harbor Islands National Recreation Area
park.name: Boston Harbor Islands

tags: Boston Harbor Islands National and State Park

stops.significance:
Welcome to Georges Island, one of the 34 islands and peninsulas in Boston Harbor Islands National and State Park. Georges Island is owned and operated by the Massachusetts Department of Conservation and Recreation. Located seven miles from downtown Boston, this 39-acre island is home to Fort Warren, a National Historic Landmark. 

Georges Island offers a Visitors Center, restrooms, snack bar, and picnic tables. Check our website www.bostonharborislands.org or with staff on island for seasonal program offerings. You can also learn more on your own by following this 50-minute self-guided tour.

As you make your way around the fort, look for the Audio Tour logo on signs to indicate each stop.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From the dock, head toward the Visitor Center, the large brick building you probably noticed as the ferry docked.
stops.audioTranscript:
Welcome to Georges Island, one of the 34 islands and peninsulas in the Boston Harbor Islands National and State Park. Georges Island is owned and operated by the Massachusetts Department of Conservation and Recreation. Located seven miles from downtown Boston, this 39-acre island is home to Fort Warren, a National Historic Landmark. 

Georges Island offers a Visitors Center, restrooms, snack bar, and picnic tables. Check our website www.bostonharborislands.org or with staff on island for seasonal program offerings. You can also learn more on your own by following this 50-minute self-guided tour.

As you make your way around the fort, look for the Audio Tour logo on signs to indicate each stop.

stops.significance:
Built around 1825, the first wharf on Georges Island supported workers in the construction of a seawall and leveling the island for the fort to be built. By the 1890s, the army replaced an expanded wooden pier with a rail system to move submarine mines and their accompanying materials on and off the dock. 

Built in 1906, the Visitor Center originally served as a storehouse for the submarine mines that played a critical role in the defense of Boston Harbor. Mines were placed in the harbor at predetermined points and depths, and connected to the fort via an electrical cable system. During both World Wars, vigilant operators inside the fort stood ready to detonate the mines in the event of an attack by German forces.

The guardhouse nearby operated as the security office for the fort and served as temporary confinement for soldiers in violation of their duty. Additionally, soldiers on guard duty covered fixed posts or patrolled a route from here.
stops.directionsToNextStop: With the Visitor Center & Fort playground to your right, continue through the tunnel until you reach a wooden bridge on your right. Turn around so the bridge is behind you to view the Demi-Lune.
stops.audioTranscript:
Built around 1825, the first wharf on Georges Island supported workers in the construction of a seawall and leveling the island for the fort to be built. By the 1890s, the army replaced an expanded wooden pier with a rail system to move submarine mines and their accompanying materials on and off the dock. 

Built in 1906, the Visitor Center originally served as a storehouse for the submarine mines that played a critical role in the defense of Boston Harbor. Mines were placed in the harbor at predetermined points and depths, connected to the fort via an electrical cable system. During both World Wars, vigilant operators inside the fort stood ready to detonate the mines in the event of an attack by German forces.

The guardhouse nearby operated as a security office for the fort and served as temporary confinement for soldiers in violation of their duty. Additionally, soldiers on guard duty covered fixed posts or patrolled a route from here.

stops.significance: The coverface served as an initial line of defense and shielded the granite walls of Fort Warren from direct fire by enemy cannon from either a broad sided ship or an invaded nearby island. The crescent-shaped stone structure within it is known as the Demi-Lune. The Demi-Lune offered defending soldiers a covered position to fire at attacking enemy foot soldiers approaching from the beach. The road to the left was constructed later.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Turn around and walk across the wooden bridge until you reach the Stop 4 sign just outside of the first archway.
stops.audioTranscript: The coverface served as an initial line of defense and shielded the granite walls of Fort Warren from direct fire by enemy cannon from either a broad sided ship or an invaded nearby island. The crescent-shaped stone structure within it is known as the Demi-Lune. The Demi-Lune offered defending soldiers a covered position to fire at attacking enemy foot soldiers approaching from the beach.

stops.significance: The largest entrance and most heavily defended approach to Fort Warren was the main sallyport. The original design included a drawbridge and portcullis, and interior slope. The current bridge design dates from World War II. The narrow windows on either side allowed  defending soldiers to fire onto attackers. The protruding iron rods fastening the inner yellow oak doors deterred attempts at breaking through with an axe.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue through the sallyport until you see a large grassy area in front of you, and turn left to follow the asphalt path around the first section of Fort Warren (Front III). You will see a large corner section in front of you.
stops.audioTranscript: The largest entrance and most heavily defended approach to Fort Warren was the main sallyport. The original design included a drawbridge and portcullis, and interior slope. The current bridge design dates from World War II. The narrow windows on either side allowed  defending soldiers to fire onto attackers. The protruding iron rods fastening the inner yellow oak doors deterred attempts at breaking through with an axe.

stops.significance:
Bastion C remains structurally unchanged from its first use. The rooms inside have been used 
throughout the years for food storage, preparation, and dining. The fort’s first bakery is to the left and retains the original ovens and remained in operation from the 1860s until about 1900 when new mess halls, kitchens, and barracks were built. By World War II, the bakery became the Non-Commissioned Officer’s Club. 

Inside the right side of Bastion C is an L-shaped powder magazine. This space is sheathed in cedar wood to help regulate the moisture and temperature of the room, in order to protect against the possibility of a friction spark and accidental explosion of the gunpowder.
stops.directionsToNextStop: With Bastion C behind you, continue walking along the path, keeping the fort on your left until you reach another large corner section, somewhat grown over with vegetation.
stops.audioTranscript:
Bastion C remains structurally unchanged from its first use. The rooms inside have been used throughout the years for food storage, preparation, and dining. The fort’s first bakery is to the left and retains the original ovens and remained in operation from the 1860s until about 1900 when new mess halls, kitchens, and barracks were built. By World War II, the bakery became the Non-Commissioned Officer’s Club. 

Inside the right side of Bastion C is an L-shaped powder magazine. This space is sheathed in cedar wood to help regulate the moisture and temperature of the room, in order to protect against the possibility of a friction spark and accidental explosion of the gunpowder.

stops.significance:
The casemates of Front II were designed for housing the lower ranked enlisted soldier. Sleeping accommodations ranged from triple-decked, double platformed bunks to single metal bedsteads. These casemate rooms housed enlisted soldiers and prisoners at various times, numbering anywhere from 9 to 80 individuals at one time.

The terreplein supported the main line of mostly Rodman cannon. These smooth bore cannons fired a 10-inch diameter iron ball. In the 1880s, grooved rifled sleeves were inserted in the bore, increasing its distance and accuracy. The terreplein can be accessed at the top of the stairway. 

In the once open courtyard of Bastion B sits Battery Jack Adams. Installed in 1899, Adams held one 10-inch disappearing rifle. This rifle was loaded while sheltered from enemy fire behind a concrete wall. A counterweight raised the gun to firing position, and after firing the recoil pushed the barrel of the gun backward and down ready for reloading.
stops.directionsToNextStop: With Bastion B behind you, continue walking along the path, keeping the fort on your left until you reach a large, brick archway.
stops.audioTranscript:
The casemates of Front II were designed for housing the lower ranked enlisted soldier. Sleeping accommodations ranged from triple-decked, double platformed bunks to single metal bedsteads. These casemate rooms housed enlisted soldiers and prisoners at various times, numbering anywhere from 9 to 80 individuals at one time.

The terreplein supported the main line of mostly Rodman cannon. These smooth bore cannons fired a 10-inch diameter iron ball. In the 1880s, grooved rifled sleeves were inserted in the bore, increasing its distance and accuracy. The terreplein can be accessed at the top of the stairway. 

In the once open courtyard of Bastion B sits Battery Jack Adams. Installed in 1899, Adams held one 10-inch disappearing rifle. This rifle was loaded while sheltered from enemy fire behind a concrete wall. A counterweight raised the gun to firing position, and after firing the recoil pushed the barrel of the gun backward and down ready for reloading.

stops.significance:
The casemates in these areas were originally divided in half. The outer half overlooked the Nantasket Roads shipping channel with two cannon embrasures each. The parade ground facing squad rooms housed 6-30 enlisted men depending on rank.

As the leading defensive side of the fort, two major structural developments took place largely due to artillery needs. Bastion A’s courtyard was covered in the 1870s, allowing for a total of five 15-inch Rodman cannons on the terreplein with new large indoor spaces below. The second development was the completion of Battery Stevenson in 1902 on the terreplein of Front I. Stevenson’s two 12-inch disappearing rifles had a range of 9 miles.

For a view of Boston Light and the top of Battery Stevenson, head up the stairway.
stops.directionsToNextStop: With the brick archway behind you, turn left and follow the asphalt path toward the large, oddly shaped gray building in the large grassy area.
stops.audioTranscript:
The casemates in these areas were originally divided in half. The outer half overlooked the Nantasket Roads shipping channel with two cannon embrasures each. The parade ground facing squad rooms housed 6-30 enlisted men depending on rank.

As the leading defensive side of the fort, two major structural developments took place largely due to artillery needs. Bastion A’s courtyard was covered in the 1870s, allowing for a total of five 15-inch Rodman cannons on the terreplein with new large indoor spaces below. The second development was a completion of Battery Stevenson in 1902 on the terreplein of Front I. Stevenson’s two 12-inch disappearing rifles had a range of 9 miles.

For a view of Boston Light and the top of Battery Stevenson, head up the stairway.

stops.significance:
As the center of Fort Warren, the roughly six-acre open field parade ground hosted various activities. Soldiers regularly formed for troop drill, assembly, and inspection. Beyond training and official functions, calisthenics and sports such as boxing, kickball, football, and baseball happened here.

Situated on the parade ground is the 1860s main black powder storage magazine. Its isolated location and stone courtyard wall favored safety over convenient access to guns. Most of the fort’s black powder was stored in 100 pound wooden kegs. Given the chance of sparks, swords, pistols, and muskets/rifles were stored in an ordnance storeroom.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue along the same asphalt path until you see another corner of the fort in front of you. You should pass a few trees and a staircase leading to the ramparts on your left.
stops.audioTranscript:
As the center of Fort Warren, the roughly six-acre open field parade ground hosted various activities. Soldiers regularly formed for troop drill, assembly, and inspection. Beyond training and official functions, calisthenics and sports such as boxing, kickball, football, and baseball happened here.

Situated on the parade ground is the 1860s main black powder storage magazine. Its isolated location and stone courtyard wall favored safety over convenient access to guns. Most of the fort’s black powder was stored in 100 pound wooden kegs. Given the chance of sparks, swords, pistols, muskets, and rifles were stored in an ordnance storeroom.

stops.significance:
Responsible for the fort and prison from 1861 to 1864, Colonel Justin Dimick resided in quarters here with his wife and two of his daughters. Union soldiers and Confederate prisoners regarded Dimick as a compassionate and considerate leader. As a testament to Dimick's character, some Confederate prisoners provided his son, a Union officer, a letter to carry with him asking for humane treatment in the event he was captured by Confederate forces. 
The rooms on the left served as the hospital from the time of the Civil War until 1906. Of the more than 2000 Confederate soldiers imprisoned at Fort Warren, 13 died after suffering from tuberculosis, measles, typhoid fever, and other illnesses. When a new hospital was built outside the fort, this area became a library. By the 1940s, the room functioned as a post exchange, selling a variety of items to soldiers stationed at Fort Warren.
stops.audioTranscript:
Responsible for the fort and prison from 1861 to 1864, Colonel Justin Dimick resided in quarters here with his wife and two of his daughters. Union soldiers and Confederate prisoners regarded Dimick as a compassionate and considerate leader. As a testament to Dimick's character, some Confederate prisoners provided his son, a Union officer, a letter to carry with him asking for humane treatment in the event he was captured by Confederate forces. 

The rooms on the left served as the hospital from the time of the Civil War until 1906. Of the more than 2,000 Confederate soldiers imprisoned at Fort Warren, 13 died after suffering from tuberculosis, measles, typhoid fever, or other illnesses. When a new hospital was built outside the fort, this area became a library. By the 1940s, the room functioned as a post exchange, selling a variety of items to soldiers stationed at Fort Warren.

Thank you for touring Fort Warren! For any additional questions, park staff are happy to help. As you continue to explore the island, please respect the rules of restricted areas. Additionally, this is a carry in, carry out park--please take all trash with you as you depart. 

For more information about the park, please visit www.bostonharborislands.org, or find us on Facebook and Instagram.

data.title: Bunker Hill Monument: Remembering Revolution
data.description: Join us in an audio exploration of what over 100,000 people commemorated on June 17, 1843, the memory of some of the men who fought at Bunker Hill on June 17, 1775, and why the monument and men continue to have relevance today.

stops.significance: On June 17, 1843, over 100,000 people crowded on this hill to witness the dedication of this immense granite monument. Nothing like it had ever been realized in the history of the young nation. It was a fitting tribute, the builders felt, to those who fought on this ground 68 years earlier on June 17, 1775.
stops.directionsToNextStop:
As you follow along the tour, please note there are some spots where the surface you will be travelling on will be uneven. Tripping hazards include raised portions due to tree roots, rough asphalt, and cracked concrete. 

From the top of the stairs, follow the path to the right (towards the Monument) for about 75 feet to arrive at the Prescott Statue.

Ramp access to the top of the square is available to the right of the stairs. At the top of the ramp, turn left and follow the path as it curves to the right to reach the top of the Massachusetts Gate stairs. Turn right and follow the path for about 70 feet to arrive at the Prescott Statue.
stops.audioTranscript:
The air buzzed with anticipation on the sunny Saturday morning of June 17, 1843 as crowds made their way to Charlestown. Reporters estimated over 100,000 people packed the grassy hill of what is now Monument Square for the dedication of the newly completed Bunker Hill Monument. They gathered to remember the fallen men and to honor the surviving patriots who fought on this ground 68 years earlier in a battle that became symbolic of the birth of the United States.  

Among these witnesses were honored guests: President John Tyler, former senator and current Secretary of State Daniel Webster, and twelve of the surviving patriots of the Battle of Bunker Hill. Over a hundred other veterans of the Revolutionary War joined them.  

Daniel Webster stepped forward to give the oration of the dedication ceremony, declaring: 

"A duty has been performed. A work of gratitude and patriotism is completed. This structure, having its foundations in soil which drank deep of early revolutionary blood, has at length reached its destined height, and now lifts its summit to the skies…We have assembled to celebrate the accomplishment of this undertaking, and to indulge, afresh, in the recollection of the great event which it is designed to commemorate."

From the beginning, Webster acknowledged that the monument represented not only the battle and the men who fought on this hallowed ground, but also something more: 

"It has a purpose; and that purpose gives it character. That purpose enrobes it with dignity and moral grandeur…it looks, it speaks, it acts, to the full comprehension of every American mind, and the awakening of glowing enthusiasm in every American heart. Its silent, but awful 	utterance; its deep pathos, as it brings to our contemplation the 17th of June, 1775, and the consequences which have result to us, to our country, and to the world, from the events of that 	day, and which we know must continue to rain influence on the destinies of mankind to the end of time…"

The Battle of Bunker Hill has served as a cornerstone of the American Revolution. The people who dedicated the Bunker Hill Monument believed it stood as a physical symbol of the values and principles for which the men of Bunker Hill fought: liberty, patriotism, and sacrifice.  

Both during the time of the battle and today, the definitions of these values remain deeply personal and fluid. Did the soldiers of Bunker Hill fight for the same understanding of liberty and patriotism? How have later generations built upon and redefined the legacy and meaning of the values that the Monument embodies?   

Follow in the footsteps of three men who fought in the Battle of Bunker Hill and consider the lasting memory and meaning of the battle and its monument.

stops.significance:
Peter Brown first arrived here on Breed’s Hill in the middle of the night of June 16, 1775. With orders to dig a fortification in Charlestown, his unit quietly marched from the vicinity of Harvard College, in Cambridge, to this location. After hours of digging in the dark, the sun slowly rose to expose their position in the middle of an open field. British cannon soon opened fire on Brown and his comrades.
Awaiting the inevitable arrival of attacking British soldiers, Brown looked back toward Cambridge in hope of reinforcements.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Proceed straight, and when the monument is directly in front of you and the Prescott statue is behind you, take a right, quick left around the monument, and then a right onto the first pathway. When you turn onto the path, the Southeast Corner Marker will be on your right.
stops.audioTranscript:
Long before the crowds gathered at the dedication of the Bunker Hill Monument, in 1775 this ground was open pasture. British soldiers occupied Boston across the river, war ships blockaded the harbor, and the entire countryside stood on edge about what was to come. 

Peter Brown, a 22-year-old white male, lived and worked in Westford, Massachusetts, about 35 miles northwest of Boston. He was a member of that town’s local militia, which meant training and exercising with his neighbors in military drill.  As tensions mounted in Boston, these military drills took on an increasingly serious tone.  As he explained to his mother: 

"Before these long threat'ned difficulties began among us, I had plan'd [to go out to] Connecticut where I expected to work the Summer; but the Allwise in his providence hath very differently plann'd my summer work." 

Brown answered the alarm called in the immediate aftermath of fighting at Lexington and Concord. He first rode as a post, carrying messages, and then caught up with the militia as a foot soldier. Encamped in Cambridge, Brown enlisted in Col. Prescott’s regiment in the Army of New England in April 1775. As he put it: 

"all business then being stagnated, and a great deal wholly broke up, I did not know what I could do better than to enlist. Therefore being hearty in the cause, I did it directly."

Less than two months later, his unit prepared for a march late into the evening of June 16, 1775: 

"We march'd down, on to Charlesto[w]n Hill against [Copp’s] hill in Boston, where we entrench'd & made a Fort... we work'd there undiscovered till about five in the Morning. When we saw our danger, being against Ships of the Line, and all Boston fortified against us The danger we were in made us think there was treachery and that we were brought there to be all slain "

After hours of digging in the dark, the rising sun exposed their position, allowing British cannon to fire on Brown and his comrades in the redoubt. Brown, determined to stay, did his best to survive as others fled for their lives: 

"We began to be almost beat out, being fatigued by our Labour, having no sleep the night before, very little to eat, no drink but rum, but what we hazzarded our lives to get, we grew faint, Thirsty, hungry and weary. --The enemy fir'd very warm from Boston, and from on board their Ships

Our Officers sent time after time for Cannon from Cambridge in the Morning & could get but four, the Captn of which fir'd a few times then swung his Hat three times round to the enemy and ceas'd [to] fire"

Men like Brown hoped for further reinforcement, as British guns roared in preparation for an eventual assault.

stops.significance:
When British cannon roared at dawn on June 17, 1775, the entire countryside awoke. New England militia units received confused information and conflicting orders. Col. John Nixon’s unit ultimately decided to assist their comrades here on this hill, entering the redoubt. Among them marched Peter Salem.
Enslaved at birth and a native of Framingham, Massachusetts, Peter Salem fought here alongside his neighbors and former enslavers. Yet here he lay, armed, in defense of this community as an unknown fate marched closer.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Proceed down the path about 50 feet. Turn to face the Southeast Lawn.
stops.audioTranscript:
When British cannon fire disturbed the quiet Charlestown landscape on June 17, 1775, New England militia rushed to face the attack. Col. John Nixon’s unit was one of the first regiments to respond, with Peter Salem, a formerly enslaved man, in its ranks.   

Salem grew up enslaved on a farm in Framingham, Massachusetts with his mother. In early 1775, his enslaver sold him to Major Lawson Buckminster. Shortly after, the 25-year-old Peter Salem, alongside his neighbors, joined his town's unit to meet the British forces on the road from Concord back to Boston on April 19.  

Answering the alarm on Battle Road, it remains unclear: Did Peter Salem now fight as a free man? Did Major Buckminster promise freedom for service, or would Salem's pay as a soldier purchase his freedom? Did his community still see him as property, or as an equal? Salem did not return home after Lexington and Concord but stayed with his unit, posted under Col. John Nixon's regiment.  Somewhere between enslavement and freedom, Peter Salem now served as a soldier. 

On this June day, Salem rushed to help defend the redoubt on Breed’s Hill. The unit had marched through Charlestown Neck – a thin strip of land connecting Charlestown to the mainland. British cannon raked across this choke point, mutilating a handful of unlucky men. Nixon’s unit ascended up the hill and joined the redoubt, providing badly needed reinforcements, as men like Brown had been there all night and now all day without rest. Even still, men like Salem had just small numbers of cartridges with which to load their muskets, and few had bayonets if the British forces breached the wall. The fight would still be a desperate one. 

Salem also served with other African American militia men, such as Titus Coburn, Salem Poor, and Seymour Burr. In fact, over one hundred patriots of color, both indigenous men and men of African descent, fought on this battlefield. While confusion and disorder plagued the response to the British attack, Col. Nixon, a seasoned veteran, sent his men to the redoubt and it is here where Salem and his fellow comrades entered the battle.  

When British forces began their attacks, they lumbered closer into the range of Peter Salem and Peter Brown’s muskets. General Henry Dearborn remembers this confrontation from the Patriots’ perspective: 

"Our men were intent on cutting down every officer whom they could distinguish in the British line. When any of them discovered one he would instantly exclaim “there,” “see that officer,” “let us have a shot at him,” when two or three would fire at the same moment; and as our soldiers were excellent marksmen and rested their muskets over the fence, they were sure of their object. "

stops.significance:
Lieutenant John Waller set sail with his unit in March 1775, to respond to the growing political crisis in Boston. On the morning of June 17, 1775, he roused his men. They assembled on the Boston waterfront, waiting for boats to ferry them to Charlestown.
When they arrived on shore, regular British Army units were already engaged with the New England militia in heavy fighting. Focused on climbing this hill, Waller struggled to keep his men together under heavy fire. Against all odds, they reached the redoubt’s walls and charged over the top.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue straight and take your next left onto the asphalt pathway away from the southeast lawn (do not go down the stairs). Follow this path; it will bend to the left. Proceed straight past the stairs that are on your left, and take the first left after the monument lodge. Go straight (the monument will be on your left). Take the first right away from the monument and face the northwest corner lawn.
stops.audioTranscript:
British Lieutenant John Waller was the Adjutant of the 1st Battalion of Marines, which later became the Royal Marines. A career officer, he sailed with his unit in March 1775 to respond to the growing political crisis in Boston. Under the command of Major Pitcairn, Marines were part of the expeditionary force that marched to Lexington and Concord.  

On June 17, Waller was ordered to march with his men to the North Battery in Boston before embarking to Charlestown. Landing near the base of the redoubt, Waller recognized that the redoubt was "render'd more formidable, by the difficult Access to it." Despite this difficulty, Waller led his men into battle against the New England militia.  

"We were soon order'd to advance and attack the natural defences of the Redoubt and to storm that also at all Events. we gain'd Ground on the Enemy but slowly, as the Rails Hedges & stone walls, broke at every time we got over them and several Men were shot, in the Act of climbing them, we at length overcame these difficulties with very little loss till we came to the Talus of the Redoubt at the bottom of which was a Road with Hedges & Trees on each side...on the part we were Jumbled together. … in this situation we received a Check...from the very heavy and severe Fire from the Enemy in the Redoubt, and in this Spot we lost a number of Men."

The British forces struggled to gain ground and suffered numerous casualties, but Waller continued to push his men uphill. Waller worked to keep this thrust organized as they approached the redoubt from the southeast. Even though today the neighborhood is almost completely developed, the hill still increases in incline as one makes the walk from the waterfront towards the monument. With each step, the slope grew steeper, and the fire from the redoubt grew more effective with deadly consequences: 

"We were now in confusion, after being broke several times in getting over the rails, etc. I did all I could to form the two companies on our right, which at last I effected, losing many of them while it was performing… had we stopped there much longer, the enemy would have picked us all off."

stops.significance:
When British forces breached the redoubt that stood on this hill, desperate and bloody carnage ensued. Peter Brown, no longer able to hold his ground, fled for his life. Peter Salem kept firing at British soldiers and officers alike in the retreat.
John Waller and his fellow British marines and soldiers pursued, but not without continued casualties. His commander, Maj. John Pitcairn, fell with four bullet wounds to his body. According to some accounts, Peter Salem landed one of those ultimately fatal shots before fleeing for his own life.
stops.assetName: The Retreat and the Pursuit Wayside
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue straight, and take your next left (before the stairs), proceed straight about 30 feet. You will pass the marker with information about the monument being erected and where Joseph Warren fell on your right.
stops.audioTranscript:
"Nothing could be more shocking than the carnage that followed the storming this work. We tumbled over the dead to get [to] the living, who were crowding out of the gorge of the redoubt, in order to form under the defences which they had prepared to cover their retreat." 

As Lieutenant Waller and the surviving British forces mounted the redoubt, they finally encountered the New England militia face to face. They charged at men like Peter Brown and Peter Salem. It is here where the experiences of our three men collide.  

"I cannot pretend to describe the Horror of the Scene within the Redoubt when we enter'd it, 'twas streaming with Blood & strew'[n] with dead & dying Men the Soldiers stabbing some and dashing out the Brains of [the] others was a sight too dreadful for me to dwell any longer on."

Unable to continue fighting through the bloodshed, Peter Brown had no choice but to retreat. He fled for his life. 

"They fell on my right hand, and on my left, and close by me, they were to the eye of reason no more expos'd than myself. When the Arrows of death flew thick around me, I was preserv'd while others were suffer'd to fall a prey to our Cruel enemies... I was in the fort when the enemy came in, Jump'd over the wall and ran half a Mile, where balls flew like hail stones and Cannon roar'd like thunder, but tho I escap'd then it may be my turn next... "

Though the British forces broke through the redoubt,they suffered great losses, including Major John Pitcairn, who fell with four bullet wounds to his body. According to some accounts, Peter Salem landed one of those ultimately fatal shots before fleeing for his own life. Even two hundred years later, the memory of Peter Salem’s heroism persisted: 

"It was Peter Salem, a Negro soldier, who saved the day for the Americans just when the British troops were ready to close in for a massacre." Cleveland Call and Post, June 16, 1960.

stops.significance:
Peter Brown, Peter Salem, and John Waller all survived the battle. Over a thousand others, however, died or suffered wounds. After intersecting in the midst of a battle on this hill, each man followed their own separate paths. None of these three ever saw fame or fortune for their fighting here.
Collectively, though, their actions on this hill became significant to others long after the battle. The acts of defending liberty, defying enslavement, and sustaining law and order have spoken to later generations in many lasting ways.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the path (it will curve to the left) and then turn right down the stairs or proceed straight and follow the path to the left to access the handicap ramp to street level. Cross the street at the crosswalk, and enter the Bunker Hill Museum (brick building with red door).
stops.audioTranscript:
Once the fighting ended and the smoke cleared, the destruction of the battle became evident. Many focused on the loss of prominent Patriot leader Joseph Warren, and the shocking toll the New England militia inflicted on the British soldiers and officers – over 1,000 British soldiers were killed or wounded, compared to the 300 to 500 of the New England militia who were killed, wounded, or captured during the chaos.  
Peter Brown, Peter Salem, and Lt. John Waller, however, all survived the battle and their subsequent lives took them separate ways. Nevertheless, their experiences on the battlefield remained with them.  
A week after the battle, Peter Brown wrote to his mother reflecting on this decisive day. Although recognizing the New England defeat, Brown expressed his admiration for the heroics he witnessed at the battle: 
"But God in Mercy to us fought our battle, and tho’ we were but few in number, and suffer’d to be defeated by our enemy, yet we were presrev[ed] in a most wonderful manner, far beyond our expectation and to our admiration... "
Brown firmly believed in the cause the men fought for during this battle, and he pledged to continue this fight:  
"Nor do I conclude that the danger is yet over, unless God in his Mercy either remove our enemy, or heal the breach --- but if we should be call'd again to action I hope to have courage and strength to act my part valiently in defence of our Liberties & Country." 
Peter Brown completed the duration of his eight-month service in the militia and likely returned home. The rest of his life remains in obscurity, but his words of the Battle of Bunker Hill have lived on.  
In the aftermath of the battle, Waller remained encamped on the battlefield, ready for a follow-up attack. Aware that word was spreading about the conflict at Breed’s Hill, Lieutenant John Waller wrote to his brother:  
"I am sat down to tell you I have escaped unhurt, where many, very many, have fallen. … I can only say that it was a most desperate and daring attempt, and it was performed with as much gallantry and spirit as was ever shown by any troops in any age. 
The army is in great spirits, and full of rage and ferocity at the rebellious rascals, who both poisoned and chewed the musket balls, in order to make them...more fatal. Many officers have died of their wounds, and others very ill: ’tis astonishing what a number of officers were hit on this occasion; but the officers were particularly aimed at." 
Months after the battle, Waller evacuated Boston with the rest of the British Army on March 17, 1776, never to return.  
Unlike Brown and Waller, Peter Salem’s reflections of the battle remain unknown. Salem continued to serve until 1780, re-enlisting four times. He saw action in other significant Revolutionary battles such as Harlem Heights, Trenton, Saratoga, and Monmouth. What drove his desire to serve? Was he fighting for his own freedom? Or was it his hope that a new country, full of promise, might recognize his citizenship?  
Despite conflicting accounts of British Major Pitcairn’s fall, some people credited Peter Salem with firing the fatal shot. Peter Salem’s role in Major Pitcairn’s demise at Bunker Hill became an even more popular legend when American artist and veteran John Trumbull included a Black soldier, thought to be Salem, in his famous 1786 painting, The Battle of Bunker’s Hill. As historians wrote accounts of the battle years later, some embraced this legend.  
For example, in Samuel Swett’s 1826 History of Bunker Hill Battle: 
"Among the foremost...leaders was...gallant Maj. Pitcairn, who exultingly cried “the day is ours,” when Salem a black soldier, and a number of others, shot him through and he fell."
In that same year, Emory Washburn wrote in the Topographical and Historical Sketches of the Town of Leicester:  
"There was residing here, till within a few years, a black man, who, we have good reason to believe, was the one who shot Maj. Pitcairn, whose death forms so affecting an incident in that bloody affray. History relates that he was shot by a negro, and from the story of the one we allude to, and many corroborating circumstances, we are led to conclude that he was the person who did the deed. The person to whom we refer was named Peter Salem; he was a servant of Gen. [John] Nixon during the revolution, was a native of Framingham, and removed here a few years since, where he died."
While historians still debate the events of the day, Peter Salem’s legacy and memory extended beyond the man. Yet he was just a man who dedicated years of his life to the service of this new country, never experiencing fame himself.  
Josiah Howard Temple’s History of Framingham, Massachusetts reminds us of the man behind the legend...
Peter Salem died in 1816 in Framingham. As pensions were not granted to Revolutionary War veterans until 1818, Peter Salem, like many of his fellow service members, died in poverty.

stops.significance:
As the scars of war slowly disappeared into the landscape of Charlestown, a renewed interest in the battle arose by the 1820s. Many prominent men with deep ties to New England believed that they were the inheritors of a great national destiny—a destiny that began at the Battle of Bunker Hill. With this belief, the Bunker Hill Monument Association formed in 1823 with the goal to construct a “permanent monument, which shall carry down to remote ages a testimony, consecrated by the patriotism of the present generation, to the heroic virtue and courage of the men who began and achieved the independence of their country.”
Because of struggles to fund such an ambitious project, it took 20 years to finally realize the vision.
But those who dedicated the monument in 1843 echoed one remembrance of the past and its meaning into the future. There were many others, and there continue to be more.
What memory does the monument echo to you?
What does it hold for the future?
stops.audioTranscript:
As the scars of war slowly disappeared into the landscape of Charlestown, a renewed interest in the battle arose by the 1820s. Many prominent men with deep ties to New England believed that they were the inheritors of a great national destiny—a destiny that began at the Battle of Bunker Hill. With this belief, the Bunker Hill Monument Association formed in 1823 with the goal to construct a “permanent monument, which shall carry down to remote ages a testimony, consecrated by the patriotism of the present generation, to the heroic virtue and courage of the men who began and achieved the independence of their country.”
Because of the challenges to fund such an ambitious project, it took 20 years to finally realize the vision. The Bunker Hill Monument Association struggled to raise enough money for the completion of the monument. In 1840, a group of women led by Sarah Josepha Hale, organized a women’s fair during which they sold crafts, art, and kitchen specialties. Due to the efforts of these women, they successfully raised more than enough money to complete the Bunker Hill Monument. 
Reflecting on the integral role women played in raising money for the monument through the Fair, Fanny Appleton wrote in a letter: 
the men do not alone monopolize the interests of the day but all the extra female fingers in the state (an unmentionable majority by the late census) have been worked to the bone for this famous Fair to host up Bunker hill Mt to a respectable [p. 3] height & this very day is displayed a goodly array of our fair ladies behind counters loaded with the million pretty trifles female brains create & needles execute. My patriotism came out at my fingers’ ends in the shape of a mock Monument, half-finished – with a scene of little work-women hoisting stones &c & one solitary ‘loafer’ slinking about it in an attitude of astonishment – a very well-designed satire I assure you on the necessity of women’s help to raise this slow-growing obelisk. " (Fanny Appleton to Isaac Appleton Jewett, 9 Sep. 1840)
This fundraising success led to the monument’s completion and dedication in 1843. At the dedication ceremony, dignitaries recognized a specific interpretation of the battle’s significance, and Secretary of State Daniel Webster spoke to the Monument’s role in maintaining this memory:
To-day it speaks to us. Its future auditories will be through successive generations of men, as they rise up before it, and gather round it. Its speech will be of patriotism and courage; of civil and religious liberty; of free government; of the moral improvement and elevation of mankind; and of the immortal memory of those who with heroic devotion have sacrificed their lives for their country.
Those who dedicated the monument in 1843 echoed a heroic memory of the battle to shape their legacy. Others have since critiqued or redefined the memory and meaning of the battle and the monument for themselves. Even within days of the dedication ceremony, The Liberator criticized Webster’s speech, printing:
It is deeply to be regretted, nay deeply to be lamented, that Mr. Webster could allow such an occasion to pass without once alluding to the startling fact—a fact which makes us blush as we press the soil of Bunker Hill and gaze upon its granite Monument—that there are in the boasted country of freedom OVER THREE MILLIONS OF SLAVES!
Listen to the words of others who have also questioned the meaning of the monument and consider:
What memories does the monument evoke for you?
How might they inspire future action?

images.title: View of Bunker Hill Monument June 1843
images.altText: A large crowd surround the Bunker Hill Monument while listening to an orator on a stage platform.
images.caption: This lithograph depicts the ceremonies of June 17, 1843, the dedication of the Bunker Hill Monument.

data.title: Calumet & Hecla Industrial Core: "The Footprints of a Giant" Walking Tour #1
data.description: The Calumet and Hecla copper mines merged in 1866 and grew into some of the most elaborate and extensive mines in the world. They sparked the creation of villages like Calumet and Laurium, housing locations like Hecla, Yellow Jacket, and dozens more. At their heart was the Calumet Conglomerate, a copper-bearing rock formation angled from southwest to northeast along Mine Street. Explore the remains of this industrial giant amid the communities it inspired on this walking tour along sidewalks and paths.

stops.significance: A long tradition of Indigenous mining coupled with settler discoveries of float copper led the United States to seek the 1842 Treaty of LaPointe. With this treaty, lands traditionally inhabited by American Indians including those from Keweenaw Bay Indian Community, Lac Vieux Desert, and others could be mined by newcomers. Keweenaw National Historical Park is located on these ceded lands.
stops.directionsToNextStop: On Red Jacket Road, you’re at the historical property line between the Calumet and Hecla Mines. Continue down Red Jacket Road towards the brick and stone building; beside it is a bronze statue created by a sculptor whose other work is in the Louvre and at the U.S. Capitol.

stops.significance: Paul Wayland Bartlett, a student of Rodin, was commissioned by Alexander Agassiz’s son Rudolphe to create this statue before World War I. Due to metal shortages, his plans were scrapped until after the war. Agassiz is posed in a metallic rendition of a C&H boardroom chair. Please do not climb on the statue or its pediment.
stops.directionsToNextStop: A boardroom chair like the one in the statue is among the items in the park collection, housed in the building beside Agassiz.

stops.significance: With a “storied” past and a mosaic of architectural features including local stone, the library cemented C&H’s reputation as a force for education in the community. Building elaborately with stone was a way to demonstrate the company’s stability and permanence.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue down Red Jacket Road, staying on the same side of the street. You will cross Mine Street, once the center of the region’s mining activity. Please use caution at this intersection. After crossing the street, you will find yourself in a parking lot beside a long brick building with many windows.

stops.significance: In another show of investment, C&H built this brick warehouse. When it proved short on space for the growing company, another warehouse was built across the street.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Taking the sidewalk along Red Jacket Road around the warehouse, you can see the former railroad grades as occasional wooden ties in the dirt on its far side. Beyond those tracks is a smaller brick warehouse on private property.

stops.significance: How’s your commute? As the mines became deeper, ladders became longer and more dangerous. One solution was to build a man-engine, which was a lot safer in practice; some thought because it was always moving and kept the underground workers on their toes!
stops.directionsToNextStop: As you return to the sidewalk along Red Jacket Road, look to your left. There, you will find a specialized wooden railcar painted in orange and black along the remnants of the Hecla & Torch Lake Railroad line.

stops.significance: When the snow got too deep for this plow, men would have to shovel the tracks, which riddled this area. A wye from where the Russell Snowplow is stationary once entered Warehouse No. 2 across the street.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the sidewalk along Red Jacket Road to the next stop, a cream-colored brick building and the home of Coppertown USA Mining Museum, a Keweenaw Heritage Site Park Partner.

stops.significance: Rather than relying on foundries in far-away cities, Calumet & Hecla established their own. Here, workers carefully designed and crafted patterns for original and replacement parts of iron and brass.
stops.directionsToNextStop: A path between the Russell Snowplow and the Pattern Shop extends away from Red Jacket Road. Follow this path until you cone to a two-story gray stone building with red stone trim.

stops.significance: The gray stone of this structure contrasts with the red sandstone trim; both types of rock are from the Keweenaw area, and were used in many buildings. They gray (sometimes with a hint of red, blue, or green) is basalt, “poor” rock from the mines without much copper. The red sandstone is from the Jacobsville formation, a Global Heritage stone which was quarried nearby and shipped for use in buildings around the region and nation.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Turn to find a low concrete structure with an iron frame over a former door.

stops.significance: Sand would hold the shape of a casting pattern, allowing it to be filled with molten metal. Its storage was necessary for foundry operations, and proximity to the railroad tracks was convenient for transportation.
stops.directionsToNextStop: In a wooded area above the sand storage, the form of a building can be seen. Please respect private property and stay on the established path.

stops.significance: When the mines were just beginning their Hecla & Torch Lake Railroad, they needed a place to service the engines and trucks. They did this in a stone shop in a wooded area, now falling into ruin. Please respect private property.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue down the path from the sand storage building to the next stone building.

stops.significance: Close to the surface of the mines they supervised, the mine captain on duty at a nearby shaft would keep an office in this small building.
stops.directionsToNextStop: The next building along your path is even smaller, and made of mine rock.

stops.significance: Gandy dancers had no need for an office; their work was along the rails. Still, their tools needed storage when not in use. This early stone building is another example of a very permanent structure built by C&H when another mine may have built a wooden shed.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Looking past the Gandy Dancer’s shack across Firefighters Memorial Park, a two-story building painted red backs the park. Make your way to the street side of this building. Caution: this is an active fire hall. Do not block fire lanes.

stops.significance: Calumet & Hecla built, supplied, and staffed fire stations at Hecla, Calumet, Hubbell, and others. This sole remaining example has a more recent one-story garage bay addition.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Beside the Hecla Fire Station stands the behemoth of the C&H Machine Shop, believed to be the largest surface structure built by the company.

stops.significance: In spite of its size, the Machine Shop would seem ant-like beside the underground world which crouched at its feet.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Across the street from the Machine Shop is a re-purposed buildings whose rounded sides alongside Roundhouse Road give hints of its past. Carefully cross the street to find its curved edge.

stops.significance: The roundhouse served to store and service the engines of the Hecla & Torch Lake Railroad; once, a turntable filled a rounded gap between its bays; today, that gap has been filled in.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue past the curved wall of the roundhouse, following the road to a dark brick building behind the roundhouse.

stops.significance: The company that bathes together, stays together? Whether the bathhouse was provided purely for welfare or to spare the expense of individually retrofitting company houses, it was a popular amenity used extensively by miners and their families. Here, like at the former C&H library, we see more refined use of now-familiar local materials.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the sidewalk in front of the bathhouse until Keweenaw National Historical Park headquarters, another unique masonry mosaic building, is visible.

stops.significance: Calumet provided more than copper munitions to the front lines of America’s conflicts; its soldiers participated in every war from the time the mines were founded, and C&H sponsored its own “Light Guard” which became a part of the Michigan National Guard.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the sidewalk to the large piece of float copper where your tour began.

images.credit: MTU Archives Photo - Calumet & Hecla Carpenters (Image#: MTU Neg 00244)

data.title: Carl Sandburg Home Home Tour
data.description: This tour is a virtual tour of the inside of the Sandburg Home. Visitors can only explore inside while on a guided tour. Due to COVID-19 guided tours may not be available at the time of your visit. Carl Sandburg and his family lived here for 22 years from 1945-1967. Learn about the home, how the Sandburg family lived here and the story of love and success they all shared.

park.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
park.name: Carl Sandburg Home

tags: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site

stops.audioTranscript:
Carl Sandburg and his wife Lilian "Paula", stood on the porch of their new home in Flat Rock, NC, and declared, "We didn’t just buy two-hundred and forty-five acres when we bought Connemara, we bought a million acres of sky!" They also found at Connemara a writer’s sanctuary and the perfect farm for dairy goats.

As you tour the house you will note that the Sandburg family lived casually.  Simplicity was the rule as indicated by the functional furnishings.

Sandburg followed this philosophy throughout his life, having written to his soon-to-be wife Lilian in 1908, “All the big people are simple, as simple as the unexplored wilderness. They love the universal things that are free to everybody. Light and air and food and love and some work are enough. In the varying phases of these cheap and common things, the great lives have found their joy.”

Connemara provided them all these things; mountain air, gardens and orchards full of vegetables and fruit, plenty of work, and the love of a family.

This study served as an office where Sandburg worked on correspondence and manuscripts, either with the assistance of a secretary or his daughters Margaret and Helga.  The room was usually piled high with filing boxes and books.  The books lining the shelves were loosely organized according to subjects and projects. 

Sandburg read the many letters sent to him daily; mail from his publisher, fellow poets, school children reading and studying his poetry, U.S. Senators, Supreme Court Justices, and even mail from various Presidents of the United States that he had befriended over the years.

A prominent feature of this room is the table constructed from timbers that supported the roof of the White House during Lincoln’s presidency.  The lumber was salvaged from a renovation project at the White House by carpenter George Severin, He used the wood to construct the table as a gift for Carl Sandburg in honor of his Pulitzer prize-winning biography of Abraham Lincoln.

Click below for an audio clip from Sandburg's address to Congress on the occasion of Abraham Lincoln's 150th birthday in 1959.

From her office in the middle of the house, Mrs. Sandburg paid the bills, answered correspondence and kept both the house and farm running smoothly.  She took care of the day to day business so that her husband could focus on his writing.

In order to manage the large goat herd, Mrs. Sandburg was often in her office studying goat lineages, calculating bloodlines and making breeding decisions based on science.  She was a Phi Beta Kappa graduate from the University of Chicago, and had a keen interest in genetics.  She sold milk to local dairies, sold goats to North and South America, and kept an active schedule of showing goats at regional contests.

The aromas of freshly baked breads, hearty soups or homemade pies filled the Sandburg dining room. Most meals included fresh garden salads, yogurt, goat's milk, and Mrs. Sandburg's special cheeses. Carl Sandburg's red thermos contained fresh brewed coffee with goat's milk and a spoonful of honey.  

While they were a very busy and independent family with a host of varied interests, they came together whenever possible for lunch and dinner. After dinner, Sandburg would often play his guitar for a family sing-a-long, or read from his current work.  Or they might turn on the radio to hear Jack Benny, Fibber McGee and Molly or the evening news. Birds entertained outside while they sat around the table.

Using fresh vegetables from the garden and meat from the farm or market, all meals were prepared in this kitchen, with the family rarely having a meal out. 

This room only contained a sink and small counter when the Sandburg's moved in since the original kitchen to the home was in an adjacent building. Mrs. Sandburg had new metal cabinets, a refrigerator and even a dishwasher installed here. The oven came from their home in Michigan.

Lilian Steichen Sandburg was married to Carl Sandburg for 59 years.  Carl called her Paula throughout their marriage.  While living at Connemara Sandburg would now and then go to the bay window in her room and lie on the day couch to listen to a record or take a short nap in the afternoon.  Then he and Paula would often go for a walk on the trails behind the house.  

He fell in love with her from the moment they met, and wrote a poem to her called Paula, a portion of which reads: 

When I saw you, I knew you as you knew me.
We knew we had known far back in the eons
When hills were dust and the sea a mist.

Carl Sandburg did most of his writing in his upstairs workroom, amid a clutter of papers, books, filing crates, and boxes.  He pinned notes and newspaper clippings to the walls and shelves.  He’d peck away with two fingers at his typewriter, which often was perched on an orange crate.

Sandburg completed several books while at Connemara; his novel Remembrance Rock, a one volume edition of the six-volume Abraham Lincoln Biography, his own autobiography titled Always the Young Strangers, and compiled his Pulitzer Prize-winning Complete Poems.

Carl wanted his study and bedroom located on the west side of the house because he knew that he would be working throughout the night and sleeping late in the morning and he did not want the rising sun to disturb this routine.

After waking in mid-morning, he exercised, doing calisthenics using Indian clubs seen resting against the chair, listening to classical or folk music on his phonograph player, and reading a little before coming downstairs for the day.  Clippings of interesting articles and images from magazines hang pinned to the wall.

data.title: Carl Sandburg Home NHS Grounds Tour
data.description: Carl Sandburg and his family moved to the property known as "Connemara" in 1945. This grounds tour will help you explore the landscape and structures as the Sandburg family and previous residents used them. As you explore the buildings and grounds you will get a sense of the history of this place, its productivity, and the creativity it has inspired.

park.fullName: Carl Sandburg Home National Historic Site
park.name: Carl Sandburg Home

stops.significance: The Sandburg Home is the starting place for the tour.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the paved drive around the right side of the house and under the carport. On your right is the house garage.
stops.audioTranscript:
Sandburg stood on the porch of his new home in Flat Rock, NC, and declared, "We didn’t just buy two-hundred and forty-five acres when we bought Connemara, we bought a million acres of sky!  They also found at Connemara a writer’s sanctuary and the perfect farm for dairy goats.

As you tour the house you will note that the Sandburg family lived casually.  Simplicity was the rule as indicated by the functional furnishings.

Sandburg followed this philosophy throughout his life, having written to his soon-to-be wife Lilian in 1908, “All the big people are simple, as simple as the unexplored wilderness.  They love the universal things that are free to everybody.  Light and air and food and love and some work are enough.  In the varying phases of these cheap and common things, the great lives have found their joy.”

Connemara provided them all these things; mountain air, gardens and orchards full of vegetables and fruit, plenty of work, and the love of a family.

Tours of the home are offered daily from 9:30 am to 4:30 pm.  Step inside the ground floor of the house to learn more and visit the bookstore.

stops.significance: From 1838 until 1945 this was the kitchen for residents of Connemara.  The Sandburg's modernized the main house with an interior kitchen and converted this building into a three-car garage.  Today the interior is used for special events and programs.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue on the gravel path to your left to the next white building.
stops.audioTranscript: From 1838 until 1945 this was the kitchen for residents of Connemara.  The Sandburg's modernized the main house with an interior kitchen and converted this building into a three-car garage.  Today the interior is used for special events and programs.

stops.significance:
Constructed in the 1840's the first owner of this property, Christopher Memminger, housed enslaved persons in this building while he lived here in the summers.  Living near the main house they likely helped with domestic tasks of cooking and cleaning, however little is known about these early enslaved workers.

The second owner, Ellison Smyth installed large wash tubs in 1924 and called it the "wash house".

In modern times, Mrs. Sandburg used the left side of the building for chickens and the right side for young goats.

Sandburg's granddaughter, Paula Steichen discusses how the family used the building.

"It was used first for chickens, and then we used it primarily for baby kids that we raised after the kids were old enough to be moved from in the basement of our house, we would take them out there.  The kids of course were separated from the does as soon as they were born so they had to be kept in separate quarters."
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue on the gravel path to your left to the next small building on the  right.
stops.audioTranscript:
Constructed in the 1840's the first owner of this property, Christopher Memminger, housed enslaved persons in this building while he lived here in the summers.  Living near the main house they likely helped with domestic tasks of cooking and cleaning, however little is known about these early enslaved workers.

The second owner, Ellison Smyth installed large wash tubs in 1924 and called it the "wash house".

In modern times, Mrs. Sandburg used the left side of the building for chickens and the right side for young goats.

Sandburg's granddaughter, Paula Steichen discusses how the family used the building.

"It was used first for chickens, and then we used it primarily for baby kids that we raised after the kids were old enough to be moved from in the basement of our house, we would take them out there.  The kids of course were separated from the does as soon as they were born so they had to be kept in separate quarters."

stops.significance: From the 1830s until the 1980's this building provided water for the early residents and even park visitors to Connemara.  A reservoir located near the top of Glassy Mountain provided the water supply.  A pump in this building then sent water to the house, the pond in front of the house and down to the barn.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue on the gravel path the next building, a small wooden structure.
stops.audioTranscript: From the 1830s until the 1980's this building provided water for the early residents and even park visitors to Connemara.  A reservoir located near the top of Glassy Mountain provided the water supply.  A pump in this building then sent water to the house, the pond in front of the house and down to the barn.

stops.significance:
Cool water from a mountain reservoir flowed through the spring house providing a perfect place for Mrs. Sandburg and her daughter Helga to store and cure cheeses made from goat's milk.

Listen to the audio for a description of the cheeses cured here from Mrs. Sandburg's granddaughter Paula Steichen.

"Then we had a little cheese house on the…if you continue on the Memminger path, where my grandmother and mother did make the most wonderful cheeses of all different sorts and flavored them with anise seeds and with all number of herbs.  My mother actually wrote an article called “Making Goat Cheese” for the dairy goat journal I believe it was."
stops.directionsToNextStop: Turn to your left and head towards the long open shed.
stops.audioTranscript:
Cool water from a mountain reservoir flowed through the spring house providing a perfect place for Mrs. Sandburg and her daughter Helga to store and cure cheeses made from goat's milk.

Listen to the audio for a description of the cheeses cured here from Mrs. Sandburg's granddaughter Paula Steichen.

"Then we had a little cheese house on the…if you continue on the Memminger path, where my grandmother and mother did make the most wonderful cheeses of all different sorts and flavored them with anise seeds and with all number of herbs.  My mother actually wrote an article called “Making Goat Cheese” for the dairy goat journal I believe it was."

stops.significance: In addition to storing wood for the fireplaces, the Sandburg's stored older farm equipment here including a poultry feeder, a baby chick house, cream seperator, plows, mowers and unused building materials.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Take the second smaller natural surface trail on your right to walk towards a low white building.
stops.audioTranscript: In addition to storing wood for the fireplaces, the Sandburg's stored older farm equipment here including a poultry feeder, a baby chick house, cream seperator, plows, mowers and unused building materials.

stops.significance:
Built in 1873 this building served originally as a root cellar.  The Sandburg's used the greenhouse side to start plants for the flower gardens and occasionally stored bulbs in its cellar.

Adjacent to the greenhouse, the Sandburg's cleared up to an acre for a vegetable garden.  The garden provided much of their own food for the year through canning, drying and preservation.  Still used each year to pant a variety of vegetables, this garden retains a strong association with its past.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Contnue walking towards the garden. Just past the garden is a small wood shed housing adult goats.
stops.audioTranscript:
Built in 1873 this building served originally as a root cellar.  The Sandburg's used the greenhouse side to start plants for the flower gardens and occasionally stored bulbs in its cellar.

Adjacent to the greenhouse, the Sandburg's cleared up to an acre for a vegetable garden.  The garden provided much of their own food for the year through canning, drying and preservation.  Still used each year to pant a variety of vegetables, this garden retains a strong association with its past.

stops.significance: Mrs. Sandburg used these sheds when goats were ill and needed to be isolated from the main herd.  The shed on the right was also sometimes referred to as the "breeding shed" as goats would be brought here in the fall for breeding.  Today only one shed is in use and it houses the bucks (boy goats).  The bucks are separated from the does once they reach four to six months old to prevent unplanned breeding.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Cross the road and head towards the gate into the barnyard.
stops.audioTranscript: Mrs. Sandburg used these sheds when goats were ill and needed to be isolated from the main herd.  The shed on the right was also sometimes referred to as the "breeding shed" as goats would be brought here in the fall for breeding.  Today only one shed is in use and it houses the bucks (boy goats).  The bucks are separated from the does once they reach four to six months old to prevent unplanned breeding.

stops.significance: Constructed in 1923 this corn crib originally stored corn grown on the farm and fed to the livestock raised by second owner Ellison Smyth.  The Sandburg's stored various farm equipment here and today garden tools are stored inside.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Walk towards the largest red building in the barnyard.
stops.audioTranscript: Constructed in 1923 this corn crib originally stored corn grown on the farm and fed to the livestock raised by second owner Ellison Smyth.  The Sandburg's stored various farm equipment here and today garden tools are stored inside.

stops.significance:
The goat barn sheltered the does (girl goats) at Connemara.  Mrs. Sandburg operated a successfull dairy, selling milk from the farm to dairies in Asheville and Greenville.  Many of the farm's goats won top awards at state and local fairs. Jennifer II, a Toggenburg dairy goat, was internationally recognized as the top producing Toggenburg in the world in 1960. 

Mrs. Sandburg helped establish the American Dairy Goat Association, located in Spindale, NC, and was its Director for over ten years. She was honored with a lifetime directorship. A legend in the dairy goat industry, Mrs. Paula Sandburg was a champion of champions.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Walk through the gate to the right of the goat barn and follow the path around to the back.
stops.audioTranscript:
The goat barn sheltered the does (girl goats) at Connemara.  Mrs. Sandburg operated a successfull dairy, selling milk from the farm to dairies in Asheville and Greenville.  Many of the farm's goats won top awards at state and local fairs. Jennifer II, a Toggenburg dairy goat, was internationally recognized as the top producing Toggenburg in the world in 1960. 

Mrs. Sandburg helped establish the American Dairy Goat Association, located in Spindale, NC, and was its Director for over ten years. She was honored with a lifetime directorship. A legend in the dairy goat industry, Mrs. Paula Sandburg was a champion of champions.

stops.significance:
The Sandburg's built the milk house in 1948 to process and bottle milk for sale on the farm.  Pipes run from the milking parlor inside the barn into the milk house to be strained and separated before bottling.  Quart-size cardboard bottles were affixed with "Connemara Farms" caps and sold to local dairies and individuals.  

After mandatory pasteurization laws were passed in the early 1950's, Mrs. Sandburg no longer sold milk directly, but collected the milk in large containers to be sold to larger dairies for pasteurization and distribution.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Head back towards the gate to the barnyard, but stop at the small red buildings on your left.
stops.audioTranscript:
The Sandburg's built the milk house in 1948 to process and bottle milk for sale on the farm.  Pipes run from the milking parlor inside the barn into the milk house to be strained and separated before bottling.  Quart-size cardboard bottles were affixed with "Connemara Farms" caps and sold to local dairies and individuals.  

After mandatory pasteurization laws were passed in the early 1950's, Mrs. Sandburg no longer sold milk directly, but collected the milk in large containers to be sold to larger dairies for pasteurization and distribution.

stops.significance:
The Sandburg's kept a family milk cow in this shed and sawdust for the goat barn in the storage shed behind it.

Today the cow shed is used to care for chickens of similar breeds to those Mrs. Sandburg raised. The Sandburg chickens were housed in a building up the road by the main house.  Saw dust for the goat barn is still stored in the shed behind it.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Walk through the gate into the main barnyard and towards the first red building on your right.
stops.audioTranscript:
The Sandburg's kept a family milk cow in this shed and sawdust for the goat barn in the storage shed behind it.

Today the cow shed is used to care for chickens of similar breeds to those Mrs. Sandburg raised. The Sandburg chickens were housed in a building up the road by the main house.  Saw dust for the goat barn is still stored in the shed behind it.

stops.significance: The grandchildren, Paula and John Carl each had a horse to ride through the pastures and along the many trails throughout the property.  This building housed their horses, saddles and tack.  Work horses for plowing were also kept here.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Turn around head towards another small red building. Wheelbarrows are propped against the side.
stops.audioTranscript: The grandchildren, Paula and John Carl each had a horse to ride through the pastures and along the many trails throughout the property.  This building housed their horses, saddles and tack.  Work horses for plowing were also kept here.

stops.significance:
Mrs. Sandburg housed her young buck kids in this building and adjacent play yard until they were old enough to join the older bucks or be shipped off to other dairy goat farms. 

Today the park uses this building and play yard in the spring for does and their new kids.  Later in the summer, once the buck kids reach four to six months old they are separated from the herd and housed here until they are large enough to join older bucks across the road or are sold to another farm.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Walk out the main barn gate to the white building on your left.
stops.audioTranscript:
Mrs. Sandburg housed her young buck kids in this building and adjacent play yard until they were old enough to join the older bucks or be shipped off to other dairy goat farms. 

Today the park uses this building and play yard in the spring for does and their new kids.  Later in the summer, once the buck kids reach four to six months old they are separated from the herd and housed here until they are large enough to join older bucks across the road or are sold to another farm.

stops.significance:
The Sandburg's stored farm equipment including the farm tractor and jeep in this building.  Occasionally the equipment was removed for evening square dances, including a group known as the Connemara Farm Dancers.

Listen to the audio to hear Sandburg's granddaughter Paula Steichen talk about the square dances held here.

"The garage at the barn was often used for square dances on Saturday nights.  When we had a caretaker Frank Mintz for quite a time who was part of a dancing group, a mountain dancing group, and we would have square dances, he would really hold the square dances there, and sometimes members of the family would go down.  I know that Frank Mintz’s group for a while wore the shirts that said Chickaming Goat Herd on them."
stops.directionsToNextStop: Follow the gravel road back towards the Sandburg Home. Stop in front of the large green home on your left.
stops.audioTranscript:
The Sandburg's stored farm equipment including the farm tractor and jeep in this building.  Occasionally the equipment was removed for evening square dances, including a group known as the Connemara Farm Dancers.

Listen to the audio to hear Sandburg's granddaughter Paula Steichen talk about the square dances held here.

"The garage at the barn was often used for square dances on Saturday nights.  When we had a caretaker Frank Mintz for quite a time who was part of a dancing group, a mountain dancing group, and we would have square dances, he would really hold the square dances there, and sometimes members of the family would go down.  I know that Frank Mintz’s group for a while wore the shirts that said Chickaming Goat Herd on them."

stops.significance:
This residence was constructed around 1915 to serve as the home for Smyth's farm caretaker and his family.  The Sandburg's continued this use when they hired Frank Mintz in 1946 to tend Connemara Farms.  He helped by feeding, milking and breeding the goats, plowing the fields and making repairs to buildings.

In the 1960's Leroy Levi moved in with his family to serve as farm manager.  Today the house is used as a residence for temporaray employees and in the spring for the Carl Sandburg Writer-in-Residence.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue on the gravel road towards the Sandburg Home. Stop at the next white building on your right.
stops.audioTranscript:
This residence was constructed around 1915 to serve as the home for Smyth's farm caretaker and his family.  The Sandburg's continued this use when they hired Frank Mintz in 1946 to tend Connemara Farms.  He helped by feeding, milking and breeding the goats, plowing the fields and making repairs to buildings.

In the 1960's Leroy Levi moved in with his family to serve as farm manager.  Today the house is used as a residence for temporaray employees and in the spring for the Carl Sandburg Writer-in-Residence.

stops.significance: This building housed the servants of the first two owners.  Carl Sandburg later named it the "Swedish House" because of the scalloped fascia and used it as an overflow library for magazines and books.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Cross to the other side of the road to the small white building on your left.
stops.audioTranscript: This building housed the servants of the first two owners.  Carl Sandburg later named it the "Swedish House" because of the scalloped fascia and used it as an overflow library for magazines and books.

stops.significance: Built around 1910, this "little white house" was a residence for farm assisstants, chauffers and family guests of the Smyth family.  During Sandburg's time it was occasionally used as a residence for farm employees or as a studio for Helga Sandburg's painting.
stops.directionsToNextStop: Continue on the gravel road (not the paved drive). When you see a white gate at the next paved road look to your right for the gazebo.
stops.audioTranscript: Built around 1910, this "little white house" was a residence for farm assisstants, chauffers and family guests of the Smyth family.  During Sandburg's time it was occasionally used as a residence for farm employees or as a studio for Helga Sandburg's painting.

stops.significance: The Sandburg's oldest daughter Margaret cared for this "wild, overgrown, and beautiful" fenced garden of roses, peonies and perennials.  She used the gazebo to store her garden tools.
stops.directionsToNextStop: This is the last stop.
