data.title: Carriage Road Bridges Tour
data.description: This self-guided tour takes visitors by a number of historic carriage road bridges. It starts from Jordan Pond House and goes along carriage roads to create a five mile loop. Duration will vary whether visitors are on foot or bicycle. John D. Rockefeller financed 16 of 17 stone-faced bridges, each unique in design, to span streams, waterfalls, roads, and cliffsides. The bridges are steel-reinforced concrete, but the use of native stone for the facing gives them a natural appearance.

stops.significance: This is the first stop and "trailhead" for the self-guided carriage road bridges tour.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From Jordan Pond House, walk around the building to the lower level. Take the path leading down along the left side of the lawn towards Jordan Pond. At the bottom, turn left and proceed to the Jordan Pond Dam Bridge.

stops.significance: The Jordan Pond Dam Bridge (1920) was the third of 17 bridges constructed along 57 miles of carriage road on Mount Desert Island between 1917 and 1940. The bridge carries Asticou-Jordan Pond Road across Jordan Stream adjacent to a small dam at the southwest corner of Jordan Pond.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From Jordan Pond Dam Bridge, cross over and follow the carriage road as it slowly ascends. At Intersection 14, follow signs for the Amphitheater.

stops.significance: Cliffside Bridge (1932) is one of 17 bridges constructed along 57 miles of carriage road on Mount Desert Island between 1917 and 1940. It carries Amphitheater Road (Asticou-Jordan Pond Road) over a ravine on the flank of Jordan Mountain along a road between Amphitheater and West Branch bridges.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From Cliffside Bridge, continue to Intersection 21. Turn right and head north for .6 miles to Amphitheater Bridge.

stops.significance: Amphitheatre Bridge (1931) is the largest of 17 bridges constructed along 57 miles of carriage road on Mount Desert Island between 1917 and 1940. It carries Amphitheatre Road (Asticou-Jordan Pond Road) -- which itself had been abandoned for ten years due to the objections of summer residents -- near the Little Harbor Brook waterfall.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From Amphitheater Bridge, continue going south on the carriage road. At Intersection 21, follow signs for Jordan Pond House and go .6 miles to reach Little Harbor Brook Bridge.

stops.significance: The Little Harbor Brook Bridge (1919) was the second of 17 bridges constructed along 57 miles of carriage road on Mount Desert Island between 1917 and 1940. It is located on Little Harbor Brook Road for a section of carriage road connecting Jordan Pond with Brown Mountain Road over a shallow and rocky brook deep in the woods.
stops.directionsToNextStop: From Little Harbor Brook Bridge, continue along the carriage road to Intersection 22. Follow signs for Jordan Pond House. Go .4 miles to Intersection 21. Proceed for one mile and at Intersection 14, turn right to finish the tour back at Jordan Pond House.

images.credit: Photo by Nathaniel X. Boëchat, Friends of Acadia, NPS

data.title: Castolon History Driving Tour
data.description: The Castolon Historic District represents the largest and most complete example of human history in Big Bend, from Paleo-Indians to pioneers, to the establishment of the national park. Castolon’s history includes famed tales of bandits, soldiers, farmers, and ranchers, in a place where the cultures of Mexico and the United States meet. This section will help you explore Castolon’s past through a driving tour that is 2 to 3 hours.

data.name: Abó Visitor Center
data.description: The Abó Visitor Center includes a bookstore and restrooms. There is a short trail through the 17th century Mission of San Gregorio de Abó, and another short trail around the Spanish resettlement structures. During the summer (May 1-October 31), the visitor center, trails and restrooms at Abó are open daily 9:00am-5:00pm. During the winter (November 1-April 30), the Abó Visitor Center is open Thursday-Monday 9:00am-4:00pm. Trails and restrooms are open daily from 9:00am-4:00pm.
data.audioDescription: When you drive up NM 513 for 0.75 miles, you will notice a gravel turn-around that passes a building; the road continues but goes to private residences. The parking is in a gravel lot just before the turn-around on the right side of the road in front of the 19th century resettlement structures. When you get out of the car, the visitor center will be to your left up a small incline accessed via a red asphalt trail. The small visitor center features a bookstore, several interpretive panels and a model of how the church may once have looked. To access the restrooms, continue past the visitor center and turn right on the paved trail shortly before crossing the road.
data.passportStampLocationDescription: Each of our three sites and Headquarters have a stamp that will say Salinas Pueblo Missions NM, the date, and the name of the site. The Abó Visitor Center has the Abó stamp.

data.name: Acadian Cultural Center
data.description: Permanent and special exhibits, an award-winning film, ranger talks, and programs share the history, customs, language, and contemporary culture of the Acadians who became Louisiana's Cajuns. Admission to the center and to most programs is free.
data.audioDescription: The visitor center at the Acadian Cultural Center has three main components: a museum, a theater and a book store. The approach to the building itself is a wide brick walkway with a slight incline. It turns to the right as you near the building; here there are three flag poles displaying, from left to right, the Louisiana state flag, the United States flag and the flag of Acadiana. On either side are green plants, trees and grasses. In season, there are lavender azaleas. As you enter through the front door, you are in a large, high-ceilinged room with several square pillars spaced throughout. From that position, there are the following points of interest: Ten feet ahead is the information desk, staffed by a park ranger. To the right, 25 feet away is the counter for the book store. The book store has tables and shelves with a variety of products including books and toys. To your left, roughly 60 feet away, is the museum. The museum exhibits are related to Cajun culture, displaying clothing, fishing equipment and musical instruments, among other items. At the 1:00 position is the entrance to the theater, 30 feet away. The theater has 175 seats with a movie screen at the front of the room. At roughly the 10:00 position, you’ll find the bathroom vestibule, 45 feet away. There is one, single-occupancy bathroom available to visitors; once you enter the vestibule, turn left and walk along a wall to your left to the bathroom door ahead. (You will pass a closest door on your left before reaching the bathroom.) As you navigate your surroundings, keep in mind that there are pillars spaced at regular intervals around the space.

data.name: Adams National Historical Park Visitor Center
data.description: Beginning November 2021, the Visitor Center in Quincy Center is opened limited hours: Monday - Friday, 11am - 3pm. The LAZ garage for parking is accessed from Saville Ave. Parking validated for free. The Visitor Center is your stop to speak with a park ranger, purchase gifts, pick up Junior Ranger materials, or watch the introductory park film. We are currently not issuing America the Beautiful passes. Pass information and summer season hours will be updated in Spring 2022.
data.audioDescription: The Adams National Historical Park Visitor Center is located in The Galleria at President's Place. This is a multi-level, brick building. The Visitor Center is on the first floor with a row of floor to ceiling windows. It can be accessed by car or public transportation. To access by car park in the parking garage located at 44 Saville Ave., Quincy, MA. Take the elevator to the first floor. Follow the hallway. Take your first right past the elevators. The Visitor Center will be the last door on your left prior to exiting the building. To access by Public Transportation take the Red Line of the Subway (called the "T") to Quincy Center. Exit Quincy Center to the left. Walk out of the parking lot and cross the street at the crosswalk. The Visitor Center will be to your left on that road.

data.directionsInfo: Traveling on U.S. Interstate 93, take exit 7 - Route 3 South to Braintree and Cape Cod. Take the first exit off Route 3 south - exit 19 - and follow signs toward Quincy Center. Continue straight on Burgin Parkway through six traffic lights. At the seventh traffic light, turn right onto Dimmock St. Follow Dimmock St. one block and turn right onto Hancock Street. The Visitor Center located at 1250 Hancock Street will be on your left. Validated parking is available in the garage accessed on Saville St.

data.name: Agate Fossil Beds National Monument Visitor Center
data.description: The visitor center is open every day except Thanksgiving, Christmas, and New Years Day. Summer hours are May 15 through September 30. The visitor center features a large diorama of Miocene mammal fossils, 12-minute park movie, and the James H. Cook Collection of Lakota artifacts, a unique collection of American Indian artifacts gifted to the Cook family by Chief Red Cloud and his descendants. Two trails are open every day from dawn till dusk.
data.audioDescription: Three handicap accessible parking spaces are on the front right of the parking lot. Concrete sidewalk goes to the right, 300 feet to a two story dark brown building with double glass doors. The doors open to a tiled foyer area. Accessible restrooms are to the right, with men's room door to the left along the wall, a locked storage door in the middle and women's room to the right. Continue straight from the doors through another set of double doors 15 feet further. The floor surface changes from tile to carpet as you enter a large room about 60 feet wide and 40 feet deep. Ranger information desk is straight ahead at the far wall. Artifact display cases are spaced throughout the floor plan. On the right is a glass door to the James H Cook Collection of Lakota Artifacts. On the left is a large diorama display of seven large skeletons of fossilized mammals behind a 3 foot high railing. A theater with a closed captioned but not-audio described park movie is through a door against the left front wall.

operatingHours.description:

data.name: Albright Visitor Center
data.description: Here you can gather park information, orient yourself to the rest of the park (including road conditions, and campground and lodge availability), shop for souvenirs, explore exhibits to learn more about the wildlife and history of Yellowstone, join a ranger program, acquire a permit for fishing or backcountry camping at the backcountry office in the basement, or use the restrooms. This visitor center also has free Wi-Fi. Call 307-344-2263 for additional information.
data.audioDescription: Albright Visitor Center (286 words) A cement sidewalk leads to the visitor center, located in a 2-story, T-shaped building with a basement and second floor, made of light brown, grey, and beige, rough-cut large blocks of stone. The gabled roof is made of reddish-orange, half-round shaped clay tiles. The building has 4 chimneys and 3 dormer windows. The first and second levels have tall windows with 12 panes of glass; a triangular area surrounding one half-circle window at center on the second level. The basement’s wide, horizontal windows, are covered by vertical wrought iron bars. The second story has eleven windows across the front of the building. In the front of the building are three, 4-foot wide cement stairs with wrought iron railings on both left and right that lead to a porch that spans the entire front of the building. The center set of steps leads directly to the visitor center entrance under signage that reads “Horace M. Albright Visitor Center.” On the far right is an accessible ramp. The stairs and accessible ramp lead to a porch on the first level with 3 sets of double doors: on the left, a staff entrance; in the middle, the visitor center entrance; on the right, doors marked “not an entrance.” Two ash-colored wooden benches flank the center doors. The porch is shaded by a roof supported by stone pillars; the double-door entrance to the visitor center is just 6 feet forward. In the back, on the left side of the building, a ramp and set of stairs lead to the backcountry permit office. The visitor center is shaded by a large spruce and two cottonwood trees at left and right. Inside features include an information desk staffed by park rangers, exhibits, and restrooms. END OF MESSAGE

data.directionsInfo: The Albright Visitor Center is located at Mammoth Hot Springs, five miles south of the North Entrance at the northern part of the upper loop of the Grand Loop Road. It is housed in one of the old stone buildings of Fort Yellowstone, a US Army fort built during the early days of the national park.

operatingHours.description: Albright Visitor Center is located in the northern part of the park near the Mammoth Hot Springs terraces. Park information can be found on bulletin boards posted at the visitor center, as well as by using the NPS Yellowstone app. Visitor center opening date subject to change. Check locally if in the park. Check back frequently for updates. When available, rangers are available outside to answer questions.

data.name: Aleutian World War II National Historic Area Visitor Center
data.description: The visitor center for Aleutian World War II National Historic Area is in the town of Unalaska. It is owned and operated by the Ounalashka Company and is located in the historic Naval Aerology building. The center interprets both the military events of the Campaign and the relocation and overwhelming hardships faced by the Alaska Native residents of the Aleutian and Pribilof Islands. Inside there are exhibits, a reconstructed 1940s radio room, and a 1940s style theater showing World War II-era films.

data.directionsInfo: The Aleutian World War II Visitor Center is located at the Unalaska Airport, within walking distance of both the cruise ship dock and the Grand Aleutian Hotel.

operatingHours.description: In the summer, the visitor center is open 8 am to 5 pm Monday through Friday.  Additional hours may be available when a cruise ship or ferry is in Unalaska.

data.name: Alibates Visitor Center
data.description: The Alibates Visitor Center is home to exhibits, a theater and outdoor gardens, showcasing the history of Alibates Flint and the cultures that used this precious natural resource throughout the last 13,000 years. It is also the meeting place for ranger-led hikes and tours of the monument, demonstrations, and numerous special events throughout the year. Open Mon-Fri 9 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. 7 days a week . Limited wireless or cellular access is available.

One can also learn about recreating on public lands in the state as well as materials for educators to bring back to their classrooms. Staffed by National Park Rangers, the center offers a plethora of information.

data.name: Andrew Johnson NHS Visitor Center
data.description: Begin your visit to the Andrew Johnson National Historic Site at the Visitor Center. Here you will receive orientation to the other parts of the park, in addition to general information, brochures, and directions. The Visitor Center houses the site's 13 1/2 minute film "Defender of the Constitution," the Presidential museum, Andrew Johnson's original Tailor Shop, and the Eastern National bookstore.
data.audioDescription: The Andrew Johnson NHS parking lot has twelve spaces. One is designated as the handicapped spot. Two are reserved for buses and/or RVs. The lot is tight, however, and many people with motor homes choose to park in the on-street spaces, which have a two hour limit. From the parking lot, the visitor will cross the Andrew Johnson Early Home yard. A brick sidewalk runs through the yard, and they may stop and read waysides or walk through the open first floor of the home, which contains exhibits pertaining to Johnson's early life. When the visitor reaches College Street, they will find a crosswalk with a sign advising on-coming traffic to stop for pedestrians, as it is mid-street and not at the designated corner cross-walk. Visitors may choose to cross at either location, but ensure that traffic has come to a stop before proceeding at both. The restrooms and water fountains will be on your right as you walk toward the main Visitor Center entrance. The double doors into the Visitor Center are manually automatic. A ranger or volunteer will be on hand to provide orientation to the park as soon as you enter the room.
data.passportStampLocationDescription: Andrew Johnson NHS has several passport stamps available at the Visitor Center. There is one stamp for the overall park, another for the National Cemetery, and one that contains an image of the Tailor Shop. There is an additional stamp created by the Historical Commission for an independent book, but visitors love to add it as well!

data.directionsInfo: GPS The GPS setting for Andrew Johnson NHS may be listed as 121 Monument Avenue, which is the park HQ building in the National Cemetery. Use 101 North College Street, Greeneville, TN for the visitor Center. Plane The closest airport is the Tri-Cities Regional Airport, 43 miles NE of Greeneville. From the airport, take I-81 South to exit 36 and follow the signs to Greeneville. Car From I-81S take exit 36 to Rt. 172 south to Greeneville. From I-81N take exit 23 to Rt. 11E north to Greeneville.

operatingHours.description: At the Visitor Center park staff or volunteers will provide an overview of the site. Here you can view the orientation film, "Andrew Johnson: Defender of the Constitution," see original artifacts, and vote for Andrew Johnson's acquittal or guilt at the impeachment display. In the historic Memorial Building you can gain a sense of place as you stand before Andrew Johnson's enclosed Tailor Shop.  Homestead tour tickets are available at the VC, and must be obtained no later than 15 minutes before the tour.
operatingHours.name: Andrew Johnson NHS Visitor Center

We expect to close the visitor center summer of 2021 and reopen it in late 2022. During the construction the park will install a temporary visitor center building. Currently the lobby, bookstore and restrooms are open.

Past a flagpole a walkway leads in front of the visitor center, next to a series of exhibits. The building itself has large wooden columns and big glass windows and doors in front. Inside there are two service desks a few exhibits and a small book store.

data.name: Appomattox Court House Visitor Center
data.description: The visitor center is located inside the reconstructed Appomattox Courthouse. It offers restroom facilities, visitor information and guidance, a 17-minute film, and exhibits focused on the history of Appomattox Court House. Guided talks and living history programs begin in the visitor center.
data.audioDescription: A red brick two story, reconstructed historic courthouse building, with steps leading to a porch and doors to enter the second floor placed prominently in the center of the structure as you approach. A brick path leads around the stairs to the entry door on the main first floor. There are four windows placed evenly, two on each level, with dark green shutters on each. The visitor center is ringed by a wooden board fence.
data.directionsInfo: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park is located in south central Virginia approximately 95 miles west of Richmond. The main visitor parking area is located on VA Rt. 24, 2 miles (4.8 km) northeast of the town of Appomattox, VA. The closest airport is in Lynchburg, VA, 25 miles (40.3 km) west.

operatingHours.description: The Appomattox Court House Visitor Center operates daily from 9-5. Inside, park staff can make visit recommendations and provide maps and informational brochures. Restrooms, exhibits, and the park's 17-minute orientation film are available in the visitor center.
operatingHours.name: Appomattox Court House Visitor Center

data.name: Arches Visitor Center
data.description: NOTE: Rangers are providing limited services outside the visitor center during the current pandemic. The bookstore is open but exhibits closed. The visitor center is generally open every day except December 25. Hours vary by season. You can learn about the park with exhibits, a park movie, and a bookstore. Rangers are on duty to answer your questions. Restrooms and drinking water are available.
data.audioDescription: The Arches National Park Visitor center is located just beyond the park entrance off of highway 191 North of Moab, UT. The building and parking lot sit at the base of towering sandstone walls formed by the Moab fault. Beyond the turn into the parking lot, the park road snakes up and above the visitor center, which leads to the rest of the park atop the plateau. Once past the entrance booths, a right turn after the roundabout leads to the parking lot and visitor center. The parking lot is spacious, with a small shade structure and picnic tables on its Northwest side. The visitor center building is located to the right-- northeast of the lot. The building itself is multi-storied and angular, painted different shades of beige, tan, and light maroon. In front of the building is an extensive interpretive plaza, shaded by two columns of ramada style roofing, one running along the Northwest side of the plaza, the other, along the Southeast. Each section is held up by several sandstone brick pillars. In the center of these two shaded sections sits a series of decorative boulders and bronze statues of wildlife. Restrooms and other amenities are located just beyond these statues along the northeast wall. The overall low profile of the building and shade structures gives the sense that the structure is part of the colorful sandstone layers located beyond and above it. Scanning the Interpretive plaza clockwise from the parking lot, several trash and recycling bins are visible near the leftmost brick pillar. The following pillar features two water filling stations, a spicket and informational panel on each side. The next pillar, which extends back towards the visitor center entrance in the northeast corner of the plaza, features a large NPS Arrowhead and the words ‘Arches National Park.’ The remaining two pillars curve towards the building entrance and feature large informational panels about wildlife and park features respectively. A section of windows with two double doors on the left marks the entrance to the visitor center building. Continuing to the right, the northeast wall of the plaza features a low bench, payphones, trashcan, and a shaded alcove with access to two gendered and one handicapped accessible family restroom. Opposite the first column of pillars, a second shade structure runs East to south. Underneath the structure, the pillars feature additional informational panels; “Climbing and Canyoneering,” “What to do at Arches,” “Park Features,” and a gold lettered quote that reads: “Extraordinary arches, awe-inspiring landscapes.” Closer to the parking lot, the last two pillars also feature low benches. A flagpole with a raised American Flag stands closest to the road on the sidewalk before the parking lot. In the center of the plaza are several large rocks and life-sized bronze statues of wildlife in Arches. The floor beneath these statues is characterized by a sweeping patch of rough, light gray cement, in contrast to the smooth orange cement of the rest of the plaza. A male bighorn sheep sits atop the largest rock, a small lizard and two ravens perch on a neighboring boulders. A female bighorn sheep and baby stand closest to the parking lot, another lizard on a smaller rock behind them. Past these statues, one enters to visitor center through the double doors in the northernmost corner of the visitor center plaza. The entryway leads to a large mural of delicate arch, flanked by two digital trip planning kiosks. Directly in front of this mural is a large three dimensional relief map of the park at about waist height. To the left of this map is the park store. Several kiosks and display shelves are present in the entry way of the store. To the right of the relief map is the visitor center information desk. Behind the desk are panels with photographs of different prominent rock features in the park. To the right, a small inlet against the large windows facing the plaza holds two televisions mounted to each wall, used for orientation and safety videos. To the left of the information desk is the exhibit hall, which leads to various exhibits on the geology, environment, wildlife, and history of the park. The exhibit hall features a large two story window that looks up towards the sandstone wall behind the visitor center, and several large scale models of arches and sandstone features weave throughout the exhibits. On the far end of the exhibit hall sits the entryway to the theater, which seats 114 persons for showings of the park film.
data.passportStampLocationDescription: Three passport stamps are available at Arches Visitor Center: 1) the standard cancellation stamp with the park name and date, 2) a version with an image of Delicate Arch, 3) the standard cancellation stamp for Old Spanish Trail with the trail name and date. 2016 NPS centennial stamp available upon request.

data.description: The Ash River Visitor Center is open during our summer season from late May to late September. Ash River Visitor Center will be closed annually over the winter season. The Ash River Visitor Center is located in the historic Meadwood Lodge pictured above. Take a moment to explore this historic, rustic building. Watch your head, as some interior doorways were constructed for shorter individuals.
data.audioDescription: The Ash River Visitor center is a historic wooden cabin. Concrete stairs lead up to the cabin from the parking lot and an accessible path leads to the visitor center from the left side of the visitor parking. A separate building for restrooms is located to the right of the visitor center with a slight path separating the two.

data.name: Assateague Island Visitor Center
data.description: The Assateague Island Visitor Center is located in the Maryland District of Assateague Island before the Verrazzano Bridge entrance into the park. As of June 12, 2021 the Assateague Island Visitor Center is open daily from 9 am - 4 pm.
data.audioDescription: The Assateague Island Visitor Center is located in the Maryland District of Assateague Island on the southern side of Route 611, before the Verrazzano Bridge entrance into the park. The GPS address is 11800 Marsh View Lane, Berlin, Maryland 21811. Parking for vehicles, RVs and trailers is available on the north and northwest side of the building. The Assateague Island Visitor Center faces northwest and is a rectangular, one story gray building with white trim. A decorative flying bird sculpture is attached to the north side of the building. A slightly curved ramp gradually leads up to a covered deck. The covered deck connects the visitor center on its east side, to the restroom facilities on its west side. Under the covered deck is a large table map display of Assateague Island. Attached to the southside of the restroom facilities is a large outdoor bench that looks out over the Sinepuxent Bay. Rocking chairs and a binocular viewing station provide views to the south and east over the bay. The visitor center has a set of glass automated doors that may be used by pushing the button on the south side of the doors. Inside the visitor center there is a book store immediately on the north side of the building. As the building continues east there is an information desk, an auditorium and a touch tank exhibit on the north side wall. Along the east side of the building are two large aquariums and a horse skeleton exhibit. The south side of the visitor center has a large anchor on display, panels explaining island movement and windows looking out over the marsh. In the center of the building there are more exhibits and panels.

data.name: Bainbridge Island Japanese American Exclusion Memorial
data.description: The Bainbridge Island Japanese American Exclusion Memorial is an outdoor exhibit commemorating the internment of Japanese Americans from Bainbridge Island in the state of Washington. Wayside markers provide history and other information. This site is a unit of the Minidoka National Historic Site in Idaho. The park is located at Pritchard Park, 3.8 miles from the Winslow Ferry Terminal. Its open year-round during daylight hours. The memorial is staffed by a Park Ranger during the summer months.

data.directionsInfo: Via public transit The Memorial is accessible via Kitsap Transit bus #99. This bus runs from the Bainbridge Island ferry terminal. Get off at the Eagle Harbor at New Sweden stop and head east on Eagle Harbor Drive towards New Sweden Road. More information can be found via the Washington State Department of Transit and Kitsap Transit.

data.name: Bandy Creek Visitor Center
data.description: Exhibits Focus on the recreational opportunities found within Big South Fork and throughout the seven surrounding counties. Facilities & Activities Ask a ranger what to do in the park. free public WiFi, bookstore; park permits; restrooms; vending machines, and ice sales.
data.audioDescription: From the parking lot to the visitor center is a step up onto a sidewalk and then a right turn up onto a porch which has access to the restrooms. The men's room is the first door on the left and the women's room is the next door on the left. Continuing straight ahead will take you to the front door of the visitor center which opens outward towards the porch. Once inside the door there is an information desk directly ahead about 5 feet. A ranger is usually at this desk for assistance. The interior of the visitor center is an open room with a fireplace at the center in the back. There is a bookstore entrance on the left side of the fireplace. Just left of the fireplace is another entrance/exit that steps out onto the sidewalk. Just outside these doors is the accessible restroom or family restroom on the left.
data.passportStampLocationDescription: The passport stamp may be found inside the bookstore which is located directly left from the main front door entrance of the visitor center and straight back through the main room. The stamp will be on a table to the left of the center of the bookstore room.

data.name: Barataria Preserve
data.description: With more than 23,000 acres of wild Louisiana wetlands, the Barataria Preserve's hardwood forest, swamp, bayous, and marsh offer trails, picnic areas, fishing, hunting (in season and with permits), and wildlife viewing. Visitor center films and exhibits explain the wetlands habitat and current environmental challenges; ranger programs are offered daily. Programs at the environmental education center are available by reservation. Admission to the preserve and to most programs is free.
data.audioDescription: The visitor center is accessed from the parking lot by a wooden ramp. The ramp begins at the sidewalk and is slightly inclined. The first section of the ramp is about 30 ft., then turns right about 40 degrees. The next section is about 35 ft., then turns right again about 30 degrees. This section is 40 ft. to the wooden deck in front of the visitor center. The deck is level. The visitor center is 40 ft. ahead. Entry is through glass doors into a small foyer then about 6 ft. to a second set of glass doors. The ranger's desk is directly ahead about 8 ft. To the right is a museum, with exhibits of the geology, biology, natural history, and human history of the Barataria region. The museum has a wide entrance and is about 20 ft. from the ranger's desk. The exhibits are along the walls and in a large island in the middle of the museum holding more exhibits. A few of the exhibits are equipped with sound; most are not. Also in the visitor center is a theater. Entry to the theater is through a door that is immediately to the right of the entrance. The theater is entered by making a right U-turn after entering the visitor center. The restrooms are outside the visitor center in a separate building. Leave the visitor center through the glass doors and turn sharply right. The building with the restrooms is about 40 ft. away. The men's room is the nearest on the left side of the building, and the women's restroom is on the right. In between are a large drinking fountain and entrance to a handicapped/family restroom. Also between the visitor center and the building with the restrooms are two picnic tables, both closer to the visitor center than to the restroom.

Note that not all GPS systems find the preserve successfully, so double check your GPS against a map. The Visitor Center is located just off of Highway 45.

data.name: Bear Valley Visitor Center
data.description: The park's primary Visitor Center provides an orientation of the park's roads, trails, and human and natural history. The interior exhibit space provides a glimpse of the diverse ecosystems and cultural heritage of the park. Audio-visual programs, shown in the auditorium, are available upon request. Ranger-led programs are offered on weekends. Natural history books, cards, and posters are for sale in the bookstore. Permits for backcountry camping, as well as beach fire permits, may be obtained here.

emailAddresses.description:
Please browse through our website (the Plan Your Visit section is very useful) and check out the Frequently Asked Questions before submitting your message. We receive a lot of emails requesting information that is available through our website. 

We will respond to emails in the order they are received as soon as possible. Due to the high volume of email, response to your message may take more than a week. Please ensure that the email address you provide is correct.

data.directionsInfo: The Bear Valley Visitor Center is located approximately 30 miles (50 km) north of San Francisco, less than 1 mile off of Highway 1 along Bear Valley Road. Travelers may approach the park via the winding scenic Highway 1, either from the north or the south. Visitors can also reach the park via Sir Francis Drake Boulevard or the Point Reyes/Petaluma Road.

data.name: Beaufort Visitor Information Center
data.description: Available Facilities: Information, maps, restrooms & first aid, Programs and Amenities: Exhibits on island ecology and history, park map, park passport stamp. Free Jr Ranger and Jr Ranger Adventures activity guides.
data.audioDescription: The Beaufort Visitor Information Center is located on Front Street in the old Beaufort Post Office building which was originally built in 1942. The main door swings out for entry and is reached by steps from the sidewalk. Just inside the main door you are in a long lobby with the Visitor Information Center to the right and public restrooms located to the left. A wheel chair accessible ramp and push button door opener (door swings out) allow entry to the building lobby from the off-street parking area on the right side of the building. There is a handicap parking area right beside this ramp. Public restrooms are located just off the lobby on the left of the main door -- to reach, turn left, walk to the end of the lobby, turn right and walk about 10 steps where you will pass through an open archway. Turn left, and step forward -- the men's restroom is straight ahead, and the women's is on the left. Handicap stalls and diaper changing locations are available in both facilities. The visitor information center is to the right of the main door -- walk to the end of the lobby, turn left and walk forward past the handicap accessible door and through a single wide door into the visitor information center. This is a single room with touchable exhibits and an information desk. This center is often a self-service facility, but if the ranger or volunteer is there you can ask for a recorded self-guided tour of the various exhibits inside the building.

data.name: Ben Reifel Visitor Center
data.description: Located at park headquarters, the Ben Reifel Visitor Center features exhibits, an air conditioned theater,and restroom facilities.
data.audioDescription: Ben Reifel Visitor Center. 331 words. The one-story, tan, wood and steel visitor center has grey concrete set of parallel to a gently sloping concrete path, lead to the main entrance of the building. The building is surrounded on its west and south side by large parking lots accommodating dozens of vehicles. The building is bordered on its north and west by horizontally layered, jagged, badlands formations extending between 50 and 100 feet high. On the north side of the building, there are three picnic chairs with shade structures above them. Across the parking lot on the Visitor Center's eastern wall, there is a tan concrete welcome sign with the National Park Service logo and the text "Welcome to the Ben Reifel Visitor Center." The main entrance is on the west side of the building, with a secondary entrance on the south side. On the southwest corner of the building, the text "Ben Reifel Visitor Center" is written in metal letters and affixed to the building. The main entrance leads to a lobby-area accommodating at most twelve people at a time. On one side is a curved information desk with a large map showing the locations of visitor services and animals within the park. On the other side is the park bookstore with a variety of souvenir and educational items for sale. At the northeast corner of the room there is a darkly light pathway that leads to exhibits about the park's resources. Beside that is the entrance to the theater. The southeast corner of the lobby leads to a hallway with three doors, in succession from north to south, they are the men's restroom, the women's restroom, and the entrance to the fossil preparation laboratory where visitors can observe and interact with paleontology technicians as they prepare fossils throughout the park. There is a hallway to the east that is marked for employees only, and to the south a pair of double doors leading outside the building. End of Description.

data.name: Bent's Old Fort
data.description: Visitors park at the parking lot and walk the 1/4 mile (1,275 feet) trail to the fort where you will be met by an interpreter wearing period clothing. Brochures and a documentary film are available in one of the fort rooms. Western National Parks bookstore is located at the left rear corner of the fort.
data.audioDescription: Today, Bent’s Old Fort National Historic Site features a reconstructed version of the 1840s adobe trading post. Archeological excavations and original sketches, paintings, and diaries were used to replicate the features of the fort, which was reconstructed during the country’s bicentennial and Colorado’s centennial in 1976. The reconstructed fort is a dominant feature on the short grass prairie. It is at a strategic location on the northern bank of the Arkansas River. The reconstructed fort has two stories accessed by stairways. Modern restrooms are available at the visitor center parking lot area and in the fort.
data.passportStampLocationDescription: The passport station is located outside the Western National Parks Association bookstore in the rear of the fort. There is a passport stamp for Bent's Old Fort National Historic Site and the Santa Fe National Historic Trail. The passport station is at 38.04027778 N latitude, 103.42944444 W longitude.

data.directionsInfo: The park is accessed via U.S. Highway 50 and Highway 194. From La Junta, Colorado on U.S. Highway 50, take Highway 109 north 1 mile to Highway 194, then east on Highway 194 six miles to the fort. From Las Animas, Colorado, on U.S. Highway 50, take Highway 194 west 13 miles. Set your GPS to 35110 State Highway 194 E., La Junta, CO.

Winter hours (early September 8 through late May) for the fort are 9:00 am to 4:00 pm. The gate is open during winter hours from 7:00 am to 4:00 pm.

data.name: Bering Land Bridge Visitor Center
data.description: Nome, AK is not on the road system and may be reached by commercial flights. From Nome, AK you may visit Bering Land Bridge visitor center which is about 1 mile away from the Nome airport. Keep in mind that Nome, AK is 100 miles (160 km) from the preserve's boundaries. You may reach the preserve by chartering a bush plane, by foot, boat or snowmobile.
data.audioDescription: The Bering Land Bridge Visitor Center is located inside the Sitnasuak Building on Front Street in Nome, AK. The Visitor Center entrance is flanked by two large exhibit panels. On the left, is a floor-to-ceiling photograph depicting a verdant landscape of rolling hills. Giant tors jut out of the ground. On the right, a welcome panel depicts Beringia, the lost continent, with an overview of the area's geologic past. Upon entering the Visitor Center, you will find several display cases containing replicas of Ice Age animal skulls and corresponding informative panels. In the center of the room, is a large display case containing a woolly mammoth leg bone and a piece of tusk. On the wall furthest from the door, is a touch screen monitor offering a variety of interpretive media, including interactive maps, 3D fossils, and a variety of Story Maps about the region. The other half of the room is comprised of a small Alaska Geographic bookstore and information desk. At the information desk you will find examples of rocks from the preserve, brochures, and maps.
data.passportStampLocationDescription: The Passport stamp and Iditarod stamp are available at the Visitor Center in Nome, AK during regular business hours.

data.name: Big Oak Flat Information Station
data.description: The Big Oak Flat Information Station has an information desk, wilderness permit desk, and Yosemite Conservancy Bookstore. In the winter, self-registration wilderness permits for the Crane Flat area and Tioga Road trailheads only, are available on the front porch. You must bring your own bear canister when the information station is closed. Wilderness permits are required for overnight stays in Yosemite's Wilderness. Designated accessible parking spaces are available in front of the facility.
data.audioDescription: The Big Oak Flat Information Station building is a one-story, long, modular trailer. An accessible ramp ascends across the length of the front of the building onto a deck. A brown metal sign at the top of the ramp reads Big Oak Flat Information Station and has a National Park Service logo. It goes on to read: visitor information, with an icon of a question mark, wilderness permits, with an icon of a person hiking, and bookstore, with an icon of an open book. On the deck, near the side entrance to the information station are two large, grey, metal bins that look like trash bins. Similar signs on both bins read: No trash, bear canister rental return, with an illustration of a bears' head. Next to the information station are restrooms and vending machines, with similar architectural features.

data.name: Big Thicket Visitor Center
data.description: Start your trip here! Get free maps and information, meet a park ranger, and learn about the Big Thicket's plants, animals, and history. Staying awhile? Watch a short film in the theater, browse the bookstore, and enjoy a picnic in the covered picnic area.
data.audioDescription: The visitor center is built like a large log cabin in the woods. Outside the visitor center is a looping parking area with a picnic area in the middle. Inside the visitor center is a front desk where you can talk with a park ranger and a gift shop for souvenirs. There's a large theater room where the park film is shown. Inside the exhibit hall, various displays explain the diversity of plant and animal life found in the Big Thicket. Restrooms and a drinking fountain can be found on the outside of the visitor center.

data.name: Black Rock Nature Center
data.description: Located in the heart of beautiful Black Rock Campground. Bookstore, water, flush toilets, picnic area.
data.audioDescription: The Black Rock Nature Center is nestled in the heart of the Black Rock Campground, surrounded to the east, south, and west by the Little San Bernardino Mountains with dense forests of Joshua trees all around. The main campground road leads south from the entrance to a small parking area in front of a single-story rectangular building with a low peaked roof. The building is painted pale yellow and the roof has bright red shingles. There is a set of 6 stairs with a center handrail that lead up to the building’s entrance. The building may also be accessed without stairs by using a sidewalk on the west side. The entrance to the building is a single swinging door that opens out. The entrance door leads to a hallway. On the right side of the hallway is a counter where rangers greet visitors and provide information. On the left is a closed door that leads to a conference room and a large map mounted to the wall showing trails in the area. After the counter on the right is the entrance to a small gift shop that sells books and souvenirs. After the entrance to the gift shop on the right is a display window with information about the current exhibit. Past the display window and also on the right is a water fountain and bottle fill station. Across from the display window, on the left side of the entry way is a bench with 2 seats separated by a low table and another closed door that leads to the conference room. The entry way has an exit door opposite the entrance door which opens out to a sandy staff parking area. Passing straight through the gift shop is a small gallery. The walls and ceiling are made of wooden planks, art is displayed on white exhibit boards. There is a low bench with three seats in the center of the room. The gallery changes three times a year to feature work from the park’s artists in residence and local students. Continuing straight through the gallery along the right-hand wall is a low ramp with a handrail on the left side. Up the ramp and to the left is a hallway with two single occupancy bathrooms on the left side of the hallway.

data.name: Blue Heron Interpretive Center
data.description: Exhibits The Blue Heron Mining Community can be visited at any time to view historic structures and listen to audio programs. Facilities & Activities Ask a ranger what to do in the park; free public WiFi, bookstore; park permits; restrooms; vending machines, and concession stand. Railroad Ride The Big South Fork Scenic Railway travels from the Stearns Depot to the Blue Heron Mining Community in a 45-minute trip. The train remains approximately an hour at Blue Heron before returning to Stearns.
data.audioDescription: The visitor information desk is located inside a small room just off the depot platform. The long platform may be accessed by a long straight ramp with a concrete wall. Once upon the platform, the visitor information center is a few yards straight and then turn to the right to access the room. The information desk is straight in front of the entrance door with a cash register. Just to the left of the doorway is a small bookstore with books and souvenirs for sale. The restrooms are outside the entrance door and right. There are toilet stalls and sinks in each restroom.
data.passportStampLocationDescription: The passport stamp is available right next to the cash register at the front desk of the visitor contact station. Ask for assistance if needed.

data.name: Blue Ridge Music Center
data.description: The Blue Ridge Music Center celebrates the music and musicians of the Blue Ridge. Established by the U.S. Congress in 1997, with support from The National Council for the Traditional Arts, the Music Center includes an outdoor amphitheater, an indoor theater, and exhibits highlighting the historical significance of the region’s music.

data.name: Bodie Island Visitor Center
data.description: Approximately six miles south of the seashore's northern entrance is the Bodie Island Visitor Center. This visitor center is located in the historic Bodie Island Lighthouse Double Keepers' Quarters at the end of a short park road off of NC Highway 12 across from Coquina Beach. The visitor center is a great place to get oriented and browse the park store. Outside the visitor center, a path leads to the 156-foot Bodie Island Lighthouse, which is open for tours seasonally.
data.audioDescription: In front of the Bodie Island Lighthouse and Light Keepers’ Quarters are two parking lots. Both the north and south lots have a curved sidewalk leading to the front porch of the keeper’s quarters which serves as the Bodie Island Visitor Center. The park store is located inside the visitor center in the room to the right. Restrooms are located outside the visitor center in a separate, small building which is located along the marsh boardwalk
data.directionsInfo: The Bodie Island Visitor Center is located at the northern end of the park along NC-12 and just south of the town of Nags Head on the Outer Banks of North Carolina.

data.name: Booker T. Washington National Monument Visitor Center
data.description: The visitor center is open daily from 9:00 a.m. - 5:00 p.m., except for Thanksgiving, December 25, and January 1. Please call the park phone at 540-721-2094 to find out if the park is open or closed during inclement weather.
data.audioDescription: The visitor center contains the America's National Parks bookstore, an interactive exhibit room, and the "Measure of a Man" 14 minute video. Visitors can obtain a brochure from a park ranger or volunteer at the visitor center desk as you enter the visitor center. The person at the desk can then start the video or orient you to the park grounds.

data.directionsInfo: The monument is located on VA 122 (Booker T. Washington Highway), 22 miles southeast of Roanoke, VA. From I-81 take I-581, then US 220 south from Roanoke to VA 122. From the Blue Ridge Parkway take VA 43 south to VA 122. From Lynchburg take US 460 west to VA 122.

operatingHours.description: Contact the park at 540/721-2094 when there is inclement weather to find out about closures.

data.name: Boott Cotton Mills Museum
data.description: Don't miss the roar of 85 operating power looms! The Boott Cotton Mills Museum includes a recreated 1920s-era weave room, historical artifacts, interactive exhibits and video programs about the Industrial Revolution and the people of Lowell. Learn more about the city’s role as a cutting-edge developer of technology and hub of social and economic change in the American Industrial Revolution.
data.passportStampLocationDescription: The Boott Cotton Mills Museum features two stamps, the main "Lowell National Historical Park" stamp (which is also available at the Visitor Center), and the "Boott Cotton Mills Museum" stamp.
